Its purity is most true, within it lies faith."*

In this chapter, the **Hundred-Flower Shame** of the **Treasure-Elephant Kingdom**, seized by a demon as a false couple, vanished without trace. Yet fate brought her to the **Tang Monk**, who carried letters and messages in return—
a tale of destiny unfolding.

Thirteen years prior, on the **Mid-Autumn Night of the Thirteenth Year of Zhenguan**—when the stars aligned with *"Zhenguan Year Thirteen, Auspicious Autumn Day"*—the journey for the **Sutra** was truly a quest for **Treasure**. When the heart first set out, the Treasure had already taken form. As the saying goes:
*"When the mind is set, the **Mysterious Pearl** manifests its image."*

Thus, though the **Tang Monk** wandered in obscurity and illusion,
unaware, **true faith** subtly permeated his path.

This was the very year and month when the **demon ensnared the Princess**—
when the chapter began:
*"Delusion cannot be forcibly extinguished,
True **Dao** need not be desperately sought."*
Meaning:
*"To sever delusion only deepens suffering,
To turn toward **Suchness** is itself a deception."*

If one but aligns a single thought with **True Practice**,
all defilements vanish—
and the moment of **delusion and awakening** is instantly clear.

Yet now, the **Tang Monk**’s single thought remained lost in confusion,
ignoring the **Golden Essence**,
lost in his **original nature**,
just as when he had been adrift in the river’s peril—
bound like an ignorant child to the **Soul-Stabilizing Stake**,
abandoned as an infant, floating on a board,
life hanging by a thread,
lost in darkness and illusion,
a masterless wanderer.

Who knew that within this chaos,
the **Princess**’s question arose—
for **Earth** harmonizes the **Four Symbols**,
secretly birthing **Metal** from its depths.

From this moment, **faith** subtly connected,
and the river’s peril could not be escaped.
**Water** and **Earth** converged,
and the **Golden Princess** returned.

**Earth**’s function was true—
the **Princess of the **Kun Palace****.

**Zhu Yang** said:
*"The Five Phases and Four Symbols rely entirely on Earth,
The Three Elements and Eight Trigrams cannot do without **Ren**."*
Without **Ren**, the Three Elements and Eight Trigrams cannot form,
without **Earth**, the Four Symbols and Five Phases cannot unite.

This **Princess of Kun** was the one who saved the **River’s Peril**.
Yet **Ren-Water** thrives in **Shen**,
and must pass through **Earth’s Shen** to complete the **Kun** form—
only then could **demons be dispelled and awakening preserved**.
The **Monkey of Shen** relies on **Earth** to act—
its meaning is profound.

**Eight Precepts** and **Sha Wujing** could not prevail in battle,
for **Wood** cannot subdue **Wood**—
yet **Wood** can subdue **Earth**.

**Hundred-Flower Shame** was the **Literary Leader of the Ladies’ Class**,
while **Third Princess** was the **Young Maiden of Kun Palace**.
The **"Treasure-Elephant Kingdom"** was the direction where **Geng-Metal** emerged—
truly the **key path** for the **Sutra Journey**.
The **"Soul-Stabilizing Stake"** was the **hidden meeting** where **incense-faith** was transmitted—
the true **target** for saving the master.

When battle raged,
a sudden cry rang out—**"Yellow Brother, abandon your blade and cease fighting!"**—
for **Earth** governs **stillness**.

First, the **Tang Monk’s** bonds were undone,
then the **false dream of the Golden Spirit** came to fulfill its vow and rescue the monk—
**deception made real**.

The verse reads:
*"Narrowly escaped the **Green-Faced Beast**,
Fortunately met **Hundred-Flower Shame"**—
to show that **Wood**, bearing green hues, became a spirit,
while **Flower**, leading the **Spring Festival**, bore **faith**.

**Faith** is **Earth of the Mind**.
The **Young Maiden of Kun**, having given birth and nurtured,
is called **"Baba"** when a woman reaches maturity—
she who mediates between husband and wife, the **matchmaker**.
Thus, the **Princess** is the **Yellow Baba**;
the **Tang Monk** is the **Innocent Child**.

A mother must protect her child—
thus, **faith in action** brings escape from peril.
A child must care for its mother—
thus, **faith’s arrival** keeps the monk behind.

The king received the letter and immediately asked his ministers and generals, *"Who will save the Princess?"* No one answered—truly a case of **wooden idols and clay statues** without resolve. For **Wood** cannot cut **Wood**, nor can **Earth** overcome **Earth**; what was already suppressed must rely on the **justice of the Golden Spirit**. Even the **Wood Spirit** like Eight Rules and the **Earth Spirit** like Sha Monk are but one-sided forces, unable yet to triumph decisively. The **rebellious demon** must be countered by none other than the **Golden Spirit**, and they must urgently devise a plan to return.

The ministers and generals proposed the Tang Monk, who then spoke of his disciples. Though they transcend the mundane and exhibit extraordinary transformations, how could they ever meet the true **Golden Spirit** and stand alone to achieve merit? Eight Rules, though master of great transformations, remains bound to **Wood**. The Foolish One said:
*"The east wind may yet suffice,
The west wind will soon be enough—
But if the south wind rises,
It will blow the heavens into a gaping hole."*

The text calls this **"foolish speech,"**
yet it is the truth.

Why? Eight Rules is the **mother of Wood**—
when the east wind first grows strong,
the west wind fades away;
but at the height of summer,
when the south wind blazes red,
it can surge to the skies and ascend straight—
this is the true principle of transformation.

Eight Rules drank wine in gratitude and ascended the clouds first;
Sha Monk drank wine to aid and urged the clouds to hasten.
**Water and Earth** united in heart,
and together they shattered the demon’s lair.

This is the logic:
*"He who seeks to conquer my strength must save my strength,
And he who seeks to conquer my strength must be overcome by my strength."*
Yet they could not escape this fate.

Eight Rules, though exerting no greater power,
was ensnared in the wilderness,
betraying the king’s favor.
Sha Monk, caught off guard,
was trampled and bound—
losing the support of his limbs.

Eight Rules is **Wood**;
the Yellow Baba is **Earth**.
**Wood** cannot save **Earth**,
yet it could shelter itself by clinging to **Wood**—
thus, the man slept peacefully in the vines.

Sha Monk is **Earth**;
the Yellow Demon is **Wood**.
When **Wood** prevails, **Earth** is ensnared,
yet even in bonds, it could swiftly be freed by its master.

Alas! The Princess,
the **Earth of Kun’s Palace**,
is the **inner Yellow Baba**;
Sha Monk,
the **Earth of Flowing Sands**,
is the **outer Yellow Baba**.
Both **Earths** entered the cave—
though divided as inner and outer,
they share the same **qi**,
with wondrous mutual aid and harmony.
Read the next installment to see this unfold.

**The Thirty-First Chapter:** *The Demon Invades the Dharma, the Horse Remembers the Monkey, the Ape Recognizes the Mind.*

The Sage said:
*"He who masters the Yellow Divide must regulate the spleen;
He who understands the body’s treatment must honor its root.*
The **Middle Palace** nourishes the hundred bones—
when the spleen is regulated, illness is cured;
**the people’s lives** are the extreme foundation of all transformations—
when the root is steadfast, the nation is secure.

If **original qi** is not strong,
and **evil qi** invades the organs,
people blame **evil qi** for the harm,
yet it is not **evil qi**—
they themselves weaken **original qi** and invite it.

If **internal warfare** is not quelled,
and **external warfare** presses the gates,
people rage at **external warfare** for its calamity,
yet it is not **external warfare**—
they themselves create **internal warfare** and brew it.

Thus, the **demon’s** reckless actions
can submerge the **Dharma** and harm the **Law**,
while **desire** without a master
cannot follow the heart and obey commands—
such is the inevitable force.

The **Daoist practitioner** follows the same principle
as treating illness or governing a nation.
When **Central Earth** is lost,
the **returning nature of Metal** is thwarted,
the mind is confused and life in peril—
this is its natural course.

The old demon abandoned Sha Monk in anger,
fuming over the news of the Princess’s letter,
knowing well that **external chaos stems from internal warfare**,
yet unaware that the Princess’s **faith**,
the **faith of returning to the Dharma**,
was the true **faith**.
The demon’s blade, raised to strike,
was also an attempt to let **evil submerge the Dharma**.

The Princess clung to life in defiance,
her **faith** unshaken.
Yet once **faith** had taken action,
speaking truth would lead to ruin—
for there are matters in the world
where **faith** need not be spoken to prove itself.
This is their kind.

Sha Monk’s prevarication on their behalf
was not **faith**,
yet once **faith** had taken action,
pointing to reality would bring harm—
for there are principles in the world
where one may lie with words
without faulting the heart’s **faith**.
This is their kind.

The Princess and Sha Monk,
united in **faith**,
transformed and harmonized as one **qi**,
mutually saving and protecting each other.
The master saves the monk,
the monk saves the master,
the master saves the monk again,
the monk saves the master again—
a ceaseless cycle,
darkly yet effectively at work,
ultimately achieving great success,
all from the **true and unerring nature of faith**.

The Half-Mountain Sage once said:
*"Knowing deceit as deceit,
yet deceit becomes truth."*
This is the Princess and Sha Monk’s **trickery of the demon** and **coaxing of the demon**.

*"Recognizing deceit as truth,
even truth becomes deceit."*
This is the Tang Monk and Eight Rules’ **driving away the monkey** and **transforming into the tiger**.

In days past, the Great Sage endured the **oppression of the Second Prince** and fled as a **tiger in flight**—
this was of his own volition.
The Second Prince swiftly used the **mirror of demon-revealing**,
branding the Sage as a demon.

Now, the Tripitaka Master suffers the **Yellow Demon’s** calamity and is trapped as a **tiger in a cage**—
this was not of his own volition.
The Yellow Demon slowly wielded his **crafty tongue**,
turning **good into evil**.

The root of their misfortune
lies in the Tripitaka Master heeding Eight Rules’ **slanderous words**,
and thus wrongly exiling the **pilgrim**—
so the pilgrim returned to **Flower-Fruit Mountain**,
grieving over the Second Prince’s **oppression**.
Consequently, the king also misplaced trust in the Yellow Demon’s **crafty speech**,
wrongly recognizing his beloved son-in-law,
and the Tang Monk was detained in **Treasure-Elephant Realm**,
while the Yellow Demon’s **magical obstruction** ensnared him.

The king took the old demon as his ideal son-in-law,
and the holy monk as a ferocious tiger—
just as the Tripitaka Master mistook the **White Bone** for a **beautiful maiden**,
and the **demon-slaying** for **harming the good**.

Why did the old demon suddenly shift from fury to joy
after the Princess’s letter and Sha Monk’s persuasive arguments?
It was not merely that he was truly fooled by the Princess and Sha Monk—
he also turned their **faith** against them,
using this very **faith** to deceive the kingdom
and devour the monk.
He suppressed his petty anger,
hoping to sell his grand treachery.

Thus, the Princess held a feast to calm her fright,
yet the demon suddenly changed his attire—
claiming to visit the kingdom to meet kin,
only to transform into a scholar at court.

How marvelous! How wondrous!
The Immortal Sage’s hidden meaning
subtly warns future rulers:
those who judge men by words alone,
bestowing empty honors,
even seizing power,
drowning in wine and lust without restraint,
devouring the innocent without remorse,
and betraying loyal ministers while defying the sovereign.

How so?
The **Kui constellation** is the celestial **Literary Star**,
while the yellow robe is the earthly **armor of the Yellow Emperor**.
*"On the fifteenth night of the eighth month, the Princess was taken away"*—
clearly, the osmanthus blossoms fell beneath the moon’s glow.
*"With an arrow, he shot the tiger to save the Princess,
yet the tiger spirit disguised itself as a pilgrim seeking scriptures."*
A web of flowery deceit,
resembling the eloquent strategies of the **Golden Gate examinations**.

At court, he spewed **Dharma-water**,
instantly stripping the monk of his true form—
fangs and claws bared, devouring the **Treasure Hall**,
his words could weave a **embroidered tiger** from his mouth.

Feasting on delicate maidens,
he relied on the **Divine Steed’s** swordplay—
yet met his match with a **full-court flush** in the leg.
Truly, his hands could cleave a **carved dragon**,
his words as they were, his deeds as they were—
a scholar without virtue—
how could he not be feared?

Thus, the virtuous do not elevate men by speech alone,
while the sage ruler must judge by **truth and sincerity**.
**Truth** is the unerring, the unfeigned.

The four seasons follow the **Dao** of Heaven and Earth without fail,
just as the tides of rivers and seas rise and fall at their appointed times without error.

When the Five Relationships lack **truth**, they collapse;
when the hundred virtues lack **truth**, they perish.
Thus, when ruler and subject share the same **virtue**, governance flourishes,
and when husband and wife align their hearts, progeny thrive.
Yet if superiors and inferiors deceive one another,
and inner and outer circles resort to deceit,
there has never been one who did not meet ruin—
body lost, family destroyed, nation fallen.

**"Truth"** is the word of a person,
springing from the heart and governed by the mouth.
When words do not come from sincerity, they become **deceitful speech**;
when falsehoods flow from the lips, they become **long-tongued slander**.
Deceitful speech confuses the ears,
while slanderous tongues topple cities.
Because of **embroidered tigers** woven from lies,
Qu Yuan drowned himself in loyal grief,
and because of jealous slander,
Bai Qi died on a peak of filial betrayal.

To invert right and wrong,
a deer may be called a horse;
to confuse true and false,
a boar may be mistaken for a pig.
Even the golden cicada transforms into a ferocious beast,
and boundless affection turns into a blade of cruelty—
all are harms wrought by the **tongue-demon**.

That the **Three Treasures** turned into a tiger—
what is there to find strange in that?
Yet the old demon, recognizing kin,
first used the pretense of hunting tigers as a means,
his words skillfully planted.

In general, deceitful men advance their schemes
by first feigning intimacy;
once intimacy is feigned, flattering words find easy purchase,
then they seek to establish merit;
through merit, favor is secured.
Thus, smooth-tongued flattery ensnares the golden-headed monk in an iron cage,
while sharp-tongued venom devours the green-faced demon in song and dance.
When such words arise,
who does not weep in sorrow?
Once a horse’s servant,
how could one not bow in submission?
The Small Dragon manifested from his body,
bowing to save the master—
success or failure, profit or loss,
were not his concern.

Loyal ministers and righteous warriors
should be stirred to action by this.
The Wood Mother’s grief drew him forward,
the Golden Official’s urgency brought him back—
scattered, then reunited;
obscured, then clarified.
Could this not be the work of a single sincere thought,
penetrating near and far?

Marvelous indeed!
The Small Dragon twisted in flattery,
singing and dancing to his desires.
With a sideways glance, he seized the moment—
five flowers, eight gates—
striking when defenses were low.
What difference was there
between the dagger of the **Poisoned Arrow** or the hammer of the **Surfing Wave**?
Though the deed was not yet complete,
it was enough to stir the heart.

Yet when the **full-court flush** struck the dust,
he barely escaped with his life by the river’s waters.
Crouched in endurance, his few companions wailed in grief.
As the poem says:
*"The horse and ape scattered, the golden and wooden withered,
the Yellow Wife parted ways, and **Dao** and righteousness grew thin."*
Truly, a cause for lament.

Eight Rules suddenly awoke from his dream,
hearing the white horse speak with human words.
Recalling the White Tiger Ridge and the White-Boned Lady’s tale,
he knew the tiger’s transformation stemmed from the white bones,
and the yellow robe arose from the white bones.
From constraint came regret,
from regret came enlightenment—
the very mechanism to turn peril into safety.

The Small Dragon spoke:
*"He is a monkey king of **ren** and **yi**,
who will surely seize the demon and save the master."*
This was the appearance of a true person,
while the demon’s evil faded—
the strategy of **End Wood** and **Pure Source**.

With tears dripping from his mouth,
his words were earnest and sincere—
how could Eight Rules not devote himself wholeheartedly?

Eight Rules saw the **Pilgrim**,
then slunk away toward the grassy cliff,
*"sliding and dodging"*—
the utmost in shame and reluctance.

The **Pilgrim** saw Eight Rules,
took his hand and led him to the Water Curtain Cave to play,
demonstrating his lingering affection for seclusion.
Yet because Eight Rules did not speak truly
but instead feigned sincerity,
the **Pilgrim** also pretended reluctance
and withdrew to the groves.

Eight Rules departed—
was he truly gone?
He feigned separation to deliver later words;
the **Pilgrim** did not go—
was he truly unwilling?
He lingered to demand true sincerity.

Eight Rules, after parting, turned back to curse,
his anger driving him to pursue;
the **Pilgrim**, though not leaving, secretly followed,
probing the truth to ensure he did not depart.
Both harbored hidden schemes,
yet neither forgot the master.

Now that the **Pilgrim** had obtained true sincerity,
how could he not reveal his true heart!

---
**Chapter 31: Eight Rules Rouses the Monkey King with Righteousness**
**The Pilgrim Subdues the Demon with Wisdom**

The sage **Treasured One** said:
In **Pali**, *"Shakyamuni"* is the same as the Chinese *"Neng Ren"*—
**"Ren"** governs life, **"Yi"** governs killing.
Killing to protect life,
killing is thus life.
To be able to give life but unable to kill—
that is not **true compassion**.

The **Pilgrim**’s killing of the White Bones was **Yi**,
and truly **Ren**.
Eight Rules deemed it un-**Yi**,
the **Master** deemed it un-**Ren**,
and thus suffered unjust demotion.
This is called **"internal Ren, external Yi"**
—not knowing that **Yi** is **Ren**.

Eight Rules, moved by the Dragon Horse’s earnest admonition,
regretted extinguishing the White Bones,
and knelt to beg the **Pilgrim** to rescue him from his peril—
this was to release **Ren** with **Yi**,
restoring him to his post as **Grand Councilor**,
and granting him authority over life and death.

Thus the Small Dragon said:
*"He is a monkey king of **ren** and **yi**,
who will surely seize the demon and save the master."*
In terms of **Ren** and **Yi**, this was the operation of the **Great Dao**;
in terms of **Metal** and **Wood**, this was the marvel of **elixir alchemy**—
one **yin**, one **yang**,
one husband, one wife,
their inversion and union never to be separated.

**Metal** is **Yi**,
**Wood** is **Ren**.
Wood clings to Metal in obedience to **Yi**,
Metal cherishes Wood in practice of **Ren**.
Mutually beneficial, they achieve the **True Fruit**.
Rooted in **One Nature**,
paired with the **Original Spirit**—
though called brothers,
they share the same **qi**;
though called demons,
they partake of the Five Phases.
If one could sever worldly attachments
and return to the origin,
then **Great Awakening** would be attained.

The opening word of this chapter is most lucid.
Yet the **Dao** of **Ren** and **Yi**
relies on **truth** as its foundation.
To a person, **truth** is as essential
as **water, fire, metal, and wood** are to **earth**.

「Water, fire, metal, and wood cannot generate without earth,
nor can a person stand without **truth**.
The **Pilgrim** rejects the Eight Precepts yet fails to practice them,
for he hates their words being untrue.
Once a word is untrue,
then no bond can be formed,
nor can good deeds be hidden.
Thus, the Monkey King’s decree was delivered:
*"That Eight Precepts is not honest at all!"*
In anger, he seized him back.

The Beautiful Monkey, sparing the **Bodhisattva**’s face,
declared:
*"I will not strike you—
only speak honestly,
do not deceive me!"*
Dishonesty is untruth;
honesty is **truth**.
This corresponds to the **truth** in the Princess’s entrusted letter.

The **Way** of subduing demons and returning to purity
depends on genuine sincerity.
Only this **truth** can turn the tide,
forbidding trickery or deceit.

The **Pilgrim** said:
*"Though my body returns to the Water Curtain Cave,
my heart remains with the **Taking Scripture Monk**."*
A loyal subject, though banished from his kingdom,
cannot bear to forget his lord for a single day;
the Great Sage, though returning to his mountain,
would never endure a day’s neglect of the **Monk**.
Thus, his earlier refusal was not his true intent—
he seized the Eight Precepts only to hasten their journey.

The Eight Precepts, sensing the **Pilgrim**’s intent,
flailed wildly and cried:
*"Look at that empty path—
how splendid to run!"*
Why? Knowing the **Pilgrim** would seize him,
he feigned useless words and instead
adopted the posture of fleeing through the air,
to provoke the **Pilgrim**’s swift resolve
and reveal his genuine sincerity.
This was the **Way**’s subtle art—
a feigned shadow to lure the true spirit.

The tale unfolds:
The Black Pine Grove’s golden pagoda shines;
the Princess entrusts her letter;
the Yellow Robe Demon disguises himself as a refined scholar,
enters the palace to claim kinship with the king,
and transforms the **Master** into a tiger.
The White Horse says:
*"Our elder brother is a man of **Ren** and **Yi**."*
These are the very events and words spoken—
yet the **Pilgrim** remains unaware,
his anger flaring, his heart stirred.

But one provocation alone would not suffice—
why? For the **Pilgrim** was bound by the **Monk**’s command;
the demon was not.
It is as if the **Pilgrim** were a retainer
left by the king to perform duties,
yet not permitted to stay.
Thus, the demon’s insult was enough to rouse him—
if the **Pilgrim** acted for the sake of subduing demons,
not for saving the **Monk**,
or for personal vengeance,
not for the **Monk**’s suffering,
then even without the **Monk**’s command,
he could act.
Hence, the **Pilgrim** feigned compliance to resolve his own dilemma:
*"It is not that I cannot go—
since the demon has insulted me,
I will accompany you!"*
This was the Great Sage’s radiant principle,
his ingenious expedient—
unfathomable to others.

The Great Sage then strode out the gate,
but the monkeys blocked his path.
He explained:
*"I protect the **Taking Scripture Monk**—
this is known throughout heaven and earth.
They did not drive me away,
but sent me home to play in ease."*
Now, this departure seems grand,
yet not truly for the sake of the **Monk** or himself.
Earlier, his rejection appeared as if the **Monk** loved him
and thus banished him,
spared him from toil,
for **Ren** and **Yi** transcend mere paths.
When the **Pilgrim** plunged into the sea to purify himself,
it was to cleanse his heart and thoughts.
The Eight Precepts recognized the **Pilgrim**’s sincerity,
with no ulterior motive.
Now, **Metal** and **Wood** unite,
and **truth** flows between them—
what could not be accomplished?

Yet, a skilled commander avoids the enemy’s sharpest strikes
and strikes where they are weak;
a master of exorcism follows the demon’s wild display,
then seizes its opening.
If one lacks the strength of restraint,
but only the boldness of fury,
advancing too forcefully,
demanding too much,
he will be warned against such recklessness.
Thus, subtlety alone can harmonize all under heaven;
depth alone can fulfill all undertakings.

From ancient times, great heroes
have never subdued demons or dismissed flatterers
without employing wisdom and strategy—
this is how the Great Sage’s intelligence
conquered the Yellow Robe Demon,
embodying the **real practice** of **Ren** and **Yi**.

The **Pilgrim** seized the two minor demons.
To capture the father, he first took the son—
attacking what must be rescued;
to save the mother, he must abandon the son—
removing the cause of her suffering.
To exchange two for one,
while the **Sand Monk** untied the bonds—
this was **earth** saving **earth**.

*"Like milk poured on the head,
sweet dew nourishing the heart—
the moment the truth is revealed,
joy fills the heavens,
spring blooms within the chest."*
This is the **true scene**, not mere embellishment.

The Princess reproached the Pilgrim for lacking integrity, while the Pilgrim countered that the Princess acted unfilially. Both examined Daoist principles at their roots: one feared a husband’s power over her, seeking to preserve her own trustworthiness; the other relied on the Princess’s attachment to him to fulfill his integrity. The Princess entrusted her message to him—an act of filial piety—while the Pilgrim subdued the demon to uphold righteousness and complete her filial duty.

Righteousness fulfills trustworthiness, and trustworthiness fulfills righteousness. Emotion and righteousness unite in strategy, while wisdom acts within. Thus, the Princess concealed herself, and the Pilgrim transformed his appearance.

Wondrous indeed! *"The Pilgrim changed into the Princess’s likeness."*

Gold can overcome water, yet why does it reverse to earth to sweetly endure wood’s dominance? The *Suishu* states: *"Without deceitful tactics, how could one pacify rebels and break through deceit?"*—this is how he fulfilled his trust.

Laozi says: *"The tongue is soft, the teeth hard. The teeth are hard, so they break. The tongue endures without wear because it is soft."* Softness thus accomplishes hardness.

Sunzi says: *"To take what you desire, you must first give it."* Giving is precisely how you take it.

The Pilgrim’s transformation as the Princess—trustworthy yet employing deceit, hard yet yielding softness—embodied the subtle Dao of giving to take. Like a cat dragging a mouse, he wailed pitifully, feigning mercy, mimicking a woman’s heartbreak at parting. Or like a hedgehog in a tiger’s mouth, he acted meekly, hiding his thorns, portraying a husband’s cruelty toward his child, bewitching others with seductive wiles.

He disrupted marriages while pretending to uphold them; he killed children while weeping for them; he stole treasures while devouring them. All was won through wisdom, not by outward appearances.

When the Pilgrim revealed his true form, he transformed into three heads and six arms—changing three oddities into six pairs, restoring the cosmos, aligning Heaven and Earth so all things flourished. This mirrored the *Bua* hexagram’s reversal into *Fu*, the symbol of renewal.

Thus, in the following chapter: *"Tang Seng regained the Monkey King, and they proceeded westward, encountering once more the season of spring."*

The Great Sage drove away the subterranean demon and uncovered the celestial constellation of Kui. The Jade Emperor dispatched his officials to subdue it, and the Princess of the Treasure Elephant’s origins were revealed. In an instant, she was returned to her homeland, where her parents reunited, fulfilling her wish to send the message and Tang Seng’s duty to deliver it. Earlier, through flattery, the water-spraying mouth lost its nature and altered its form; now, with true incantations, the demon’s qi retreated, and its original body was restored. No longer was there the confusion of the White-Bone Lady.

For evil and righteousness diverge, yet the conflict hinges on a single thought. True and false intermingle in enlightenment, ultimately sharing the same source. The Princess’s sincere trust led her from falsehood to truth, exhausting the path.

If one mistakenly takes falsehood for truth, then the demon is not the Sage—even if elixirs are swallowed, it remains like releasing a stolen heart. How could one fail to discern this?

The Great Sage returned to the Three Treasures, though as a disciple returning to his master, it was as if his heart reunited with his body, or a ruler restored to his kingdom—*"When the heart is upright, all is upright; when the ruler is virtuous, all are virtuous."*

Thus, the concluding words: *"The king returns to the treasure hall to stabilize the realm, the monk proceeds to the Thunderclap Peak to seek the Buddha."*

From the twenty-eighth chapter to this point, it is clear that after obtaining the elixir, one must still awaken to nature and clarify the heart. From striving to rest, from labor to ease, gradually reaching the state of *wuwei* and transformation. The meaning will be clear in the subsequent chapters’ dialogues between master and disciples.

**Chapter Thirty-Two: The Official of Pingding Mountain Delivers the Message, the Wood Mother of the Lotus Cave Meets Disaster**

A disciple of enlightenment said: If one understands the profound meaning of the six characters *"Pingding Mountain, Lotus Cave,"* then the following three chapters—where mountains press down, elixirs are refined, and illusions of Heaven and Earth are fabricated—along with the four chapters involving the As-You-Wish Jewel and the Golden Snare binding Sun Wukong, the gourd containing the Pilgrim, the female Nuwa mending the sky with stone, the banana fan’s true fire, and the bottle containing Sun Wukong—all their mysteries will be revealed.

As for the mountain, why is it called *Pingding*? At the beginning of the chapter, it states: *"The master and disciples were of one heart and body, all heading toward the Western Land."* West refers to the *Xie* (兑) position.

*Xie* is the hexagram of the maiden, depicted as (☵☰☵), three lines: one yin above, two yang below—two metals and one earth.

The three lines of *Kun* (☷) form *Xie*; *Xie* is the maiden, the upper line of *Kun* (☷☵).

Collectively, the six lines of *Kun* represent six hundred *li*. Below *Xie* is (☰☰), two yang lines—belonging to *Qian* (☰), metal—symbolizing the Golden Angle and Silver Angle, representing mountains. When the earth star is level, the metal star forms angles, likening mountains.

The Buddha said: *"I have a treasure hidden in the Form Mountain. Do you all recognize it?"* Master Yuanjue Chan said: *"At the top of the head, shining brightly—this is the Dao without Dao, called the true Dao."* This is like the pearl within the oyster, the profound meaning of Pingding Mountain.

*"Within it is a cave named Lotus."* Flowers are the manifestation of yang qi. The lotus blooms when yin follows the peak of yang, as in the *"Awakening to Reality"* passage: *"Next, the red flower emerges, followed by yin."* And *"The maiden’s flower first blooms in the northern land."*

Since *Xie* is the maiden, she internally nurtures the golden lotus, embodying the Five Treasures, capable of transforming treasures into demons or demons into treasures. Those refining the elixir believe demons possess treasures; by activating their spiritual mechanisms, they can steal the Purple-Gold Gourd. Ultimately, the gourd still belongs to Sun, as demons are transformed into elixir through demonic illusions.

If one doubts that treasures are not demons and complacently indulges in idle speculation, unable to escape the **幌金绳** (deceptive golden noose) and **圈套** (traps), then Tang Seng will still be devoured by the demon’s mouth—thus, transforming humans into demons through human illusions.

The Master Ziyou said:
*"The righteous practicing evil methods will see those methods return to righteousness;
The wicked practicing righteous methods will see those methods return to wickedness."*
Upside and downside, forward and backward—all arise from this, entering and exiting one another. Only when the **灵台** (numinous platform) is clear and one thoroughly understands the core principle will there be no doubt or fear.

Thus, I specially cite a few lines from the *Heart Sutra* to guide the lost.

Again, fearing that one may not grasp the *Heart Sutra*’s profundity—without first establishing a foundation—yet hastily rushing toward non-action—I also cite:
*"After completion of the work, when causes cease and the method becomes empty, naturally the body attains ease,"*
to clarify the sequence of effects.

The **功曹** (official of merit) transforms into a woodcutter to deliver the message.
This message elucidates the **宝象国** (Treasure-Elephant Kingdom)’s **百花羞** (Hundred-Flower Shame), emphasizing the infallibility of year, month, day, and hour to record the truth of its transmission, thus tightly linking it to the preceding passage as a guiding outline.

The most awakening phrase is *"must be in a stupor."* Why?
The *Rites* say: *"A bride is wed at dusk."* This signifies the union of yang departing and yin arriving.
Adding the maiden to marriage—few do not become stuporous upon marriage. To encounter this demon without stupor is impossible in this world.
The *Odes* say: *"That stupor is not wisdom."*
And again: *"Behold your dazed state."*
Truly deserving of tears and lamentation.
The Pilgrim weeps once, now wishing to recruit a heart-friend to jointly refine this demon.

For if one is weak in strength and solitary in form, then standing before the furnace will be futile;
But with united hearts and cooperative effort, the true fruit can be attained.
The master and disciple understand this at a glance, hence:
*"To cross this mountain, one must have Zhu Bajie."*

The pig is the **亥木** (Hai Wood), and wood can generate fire. If one does not grasp the subtle timing of fire and instead loses heart and scatters their efforts, how can they gather and apply their work?
Without Bajie’s fierce support, yet constantly invoking *"scattering the fire,"* this is the first and greatest peril of elixir refinement.
The patrol of the mountain was to exhort students, to probe the hidden truths within, and to caution against self-deception that leads to ruin.

The account of Bajie’s deceit and doubt reveals that while people may laugh at his stupidity, they fail to recognize that it mirrors the deluded misconceptions of all students under demonic influence—worthy of tears. Thus, the Pilgrim coldly laughs in place of weeping.
This cold laughter is more painful than tears.

The immortal master, fearing readers might not grasp the figurative depiction, specially adds the phrase *"drawing shadows and depicting forms,"*
—one to show the **Dao/Way’s** divine essence, the other to convey the figurative intent.
If one says, *"This is the marvelous method of capturing the spirit through depiction!"*
Does it truly describe Bajie’s stupidity?
One must truly comprehend the **red grass slope** where he stretches his waist—his heart in stupor and vision obscured;
The **woodpecker’s beak bleeding**—his heart in stupor and speech unguarded;
The **flying ear** struck again—his heart in stupor and hearing dull.
With the three external treasures (eyes, ears, mouth) failing, his heart’s obstinacy has already turned to stone.
He takes the **Stone Monkey** as teacher and friend, yet the mountain and cave are all stone.
*"My heart is not stone,"* yet he claims there is gold within, mistakenly pointing to the gold vein and recklessly guessing *"nailing iron leaves to the door."*
Is this the true meaning of the *Heart Sutra*?
*"Old Pig’s heart is flustered and cannot recall the truth"*—a concise summation.

With the three internal treasures (mind, breath, spirit) failing, his heart’s doubt has already turned to a ghost.
The tiger passes, the wind blows, the crows call—animals, plants, and all things are ghosts.
*"Loading a cart with ghosts,"* yet not personally receiving direct instruction, he assumes he can forcibly guess transformations and attain the demon’s perverse heart-realm by himself.
Self-surprised and self-blamed—what fault is there with others?

The **golden and silver kings** of Pingding Mountain’s Lotus Cave—are they not present before one’s eyes?
Once captured by a single drumbeat, they suffer misfortune—all due to failing to grasp the true message of fire timing and instead blindly acting in error.

The immortal master, embodying Heaven’s teachings, uses the metaphor of *"drawing shadows and depicting forms"* to illustrate the image of the **dragon-horse bearing the diagram**, revealing the source of the Dao, hence *"five mouths linked to the horse."*
The master and disciple’s single diagram clarifies the *River Diagram*’s **three-five** essence, all emanating from the **太极** (Supreme Ultimate).

Ah! These few words of profound mystery are difficult to describe—yet a single brushstroke of vermilion and indigo captures the marvelous transformation.

After carefully studying the last three sections, one attains their profundity.

---
**Thirty-Third Chapter: External Path Misleads True Nature, Original Heart Assisted by the Primordial Spirit**

Master Yu-Yi said:
The **Dao/Way** of the **golden elixir** originates from the *Zhou Yi* (Book of Changes) **Eight Trigrams**, which in turn originate from the *River Diagram*.
Heaven does not cherish the Dao, so the **dragon-horse bore the diagram** and emerged, guiding the ages of confusion—this is the *"true scripture without words."*

The *Lo Shu* diagram: **one, nine, three, seven** occupy the four cardinal directions;
**two, four, six, eight** occupy the four corners;
**five** resides at the center.
For **gold and water** generate each other—**Heaven One** and **Earth Four** combine as **one-five**;
**wood and fire** generate each other—**Earth Two** and **Heaven Three** combine as **one-five**;
**earth’s number** resides at the center, as **one-five**.
The Five Phases gather and harmonize—**three-five**’s wondrous convergence—an endless cycle of primordial essence.

Yet:
**Heaven One** generates water, **Earth Six** completes it;
**Earth Two** generates fire, **Heaven Seven** completes it;
**Heaven Three** generates wood, **Earth Eight** completes it;
**Earth Four** generates metal, **Heaven Nine** completes it;
**Heaven Five** generates earth, **Earth Ten** completes it.
The logic of generation unfolds in forward and reverse, hidden and revealed, beyond measure—all due to the **先天真一之气** (preheavenly true unity qi) spiraling within.

The adept cultivates the elixir, knowing the Five Phases in their **sequential order**—wood can generate fire;
knowing the Five Phases in **reverse order**—the mother conceals the child in the womb.
Yet fire can in turn generate wood, for within the yang lies the true yin—**the profound mystery of Heaven Three generating wood**.

The adept knows the Five Phases in their **sequential order**—metal can generate water;
knowing the Five Phases in **reverse order**—the child returns to produce the mother.
Yet water can in turn generate metal, for within the yin lies the true yang—**the genuine essence of Earth Four generating metal**.

Those who understand this are called **enlightened**, not deceived by external Daoist teachings;
those who attain this are called **divine**, not exceeding the primordial origin’s inherent power.

Zǐ Yóu said:
*"To exhaust one’s heart is to know one’s nature;
to know one’s nature is to know Heaven."*

The knowing know this, the exhaustive exhaust this—nothing more.

The metaphors within this passage—**embedding Heaven** and **releasing Heaven**—are but **the universe within a sleeve, sun and moon in a jar**, fundamentally no stranger than the ordinary.

The **Immortal Master** expounds these principles to reveal their subtleties, disseminating them widely among both refined and common folk, so that the wise and foolish alike may witness them and thus hope to **grasp their meaning intuitively**.

For instance, at the passage’s outset:
*"Taking the Eight Precepts into the cave"*—the Eight Precepts, wood by nature, are **restrained by Heaven Four’s metal**.
Immersed in the **Pure Water Pool**—
the Eight Precepts, wood containing fire, are **subdued by Earth Six’s water**, thus **encountering demonic forces in their natural order**.

Examining the diagram:
**San Zàng** represents the **Supreme Ultimate**.
*"Only seeing auspicious clouds wafting and celestial qi swirling"*—this is the **intermingling of Heaven and Earth’s primordial vapors**.
*"The traveler before the horse drops his talismans—above three, below four, left five, right six"*—
if taken literally as a **superficial interpretation of the text’s constraints**, one loses its **profound meaning**.
If the talismans are understood as **three odd and four even, five flowers and six doors**, one also misses their **true essence**.

The **talismans before the horse** properly demonstrate the **Dragon Horse’s *Hé Tú* numbers**.
Heaven Three generates wood, Earth Four generates metal—**three and four** are the **metal and wood** in union.
Metal and wood **converge through earth**, hence **left five** is Heaven Five generating earth,
and **right six** is Earth Six completing water.

The **essence of refining the elixir** is thus **comprehensively outlined in the entire diagram**.

Yet, **Three envelops Heaven One**—**Heaven One generates water**—**Earth Two generates fire**;
**wood contains water**, **metal contains fire** as well.
**Three and Five interpenetrate**, **Heaven Seven completes** it.
**Metal clings tenderly to wood**, **wood yields to metal**—
**Three and Five interpenetrate**, **Earth Eight completes** it.
**Three and Five combine into One Five**, **One Five combines into One Earth**—
**Three and Six interpenetrate**, **Four and Five interpenetrate**, **Heaven Nine completes** it.
**Wood can generate water**, **metal can generate fire**—
**Four and Six interpenetrate**, **Earth Ten completes** it.
**This exhausts the principles of yin and yang, the Five Phases**, and their **cyclical generation and decline**.

**Five and Six interpenetrate**—**having reached Ten**, they return to One**—
**still One, the primordial *Tài Jí* (Great Polarity)**.
**This encompasses the Dao of reversing perverse applications and restoring harmony**—
**for within it lies the Way**.

**Only here does the *qi* of the Primordial One**—
**swirling above, below, left, and right**—
**reveal itself as an entire *Hé Tú* (River Diagram) and *Luó Shū* (Luo Book),
**a complete *Zhōu Yì* (Book of Changes)**.
**Yet when the elixir discards the path of perverse application**, **its true Dao is already manifest**.

**The stroke of a true immortal’s pen!**
Thus, the demon beholds it and says: *"Words are not in vain—truly authentic."*

The *Fu* (Joy) manifests as the White Tiger—
when the tiger is about to devour a man, it must first humble its posture.

The demon sought to deceive Tang Seng well,
so it first assumed a yielding, humble form,
to trip his footing and disrupt his center—
thus becoming a demon.

For *Fu* is the fifth hexagram of the *Zhōu Yì*,
a transformation of *Shì* (Obstruction)—water and mountain.
*"The traveler bears [the demon] on his back,"*
its *Gèn* (Stopping) aspect—
*Gèn* is mountain, stopping his back,
so he halts and cannot proceed.

Mountain and marsh exchange *qi*—
thus it dispatches the mountain.
When dispatched three times, it becomes three *yīn*,
added to three *yáng*, forming *Tài* (Peace).
The marsh-mountain *Xián* (Binding)—
that is *Dì-Tiān Tài* (Earth-Heaven Peace),
called *"Tài Mountain presses the head,"*
earth above heaven.

The Five Phases of the two realms’ mountains,
the two *qi* of Tài Mountain—
once united in the Primordial,
entering the Post-Heaven—
how could it not stop his back,
halting him from moving?

Thus it seized Sha Wujing and seized Sanzang,
all halted and unable to proceed.

*"The Purple-Gold Red Gourd"*—the *Lí* hexagram, fire,
belonging to the heart, held by the cunning ghost;
*"The Sheep-Fat Jade Pure Bottle"*—the *Kǎn* hexagram, water,
belonging to the kidneys, held by the nimble insect.

*Kǎn* and *Lí* cannot be separated—
using the gold gourd, the jade bottle follows,
by natural law.

*"Bottom up, mouth down"*—
the inverted symbol,
able to reverse and restrain *Lí*-fire so it does not flare upward,
able to melt all true essences—
thus it is Laozi’s treasure for refining the elixir.

Why does it respond when called and enter?
Sound is the *qi* of the heart.
Like sounds attract, like *qi* seeks its match.
As the *Lí* palace’s female call,
it summons the *Kǎn* palace’s male to harmonize.
Thus it can transform elixir into demon,
or demon into elixir.
The marvel of resonance lies only in response or no response,
orthodox or perverse application—
a single breath, a single inhalation.

The Great Sage pressed beneath the Five Phases Mountain—
this is the Dao-heart unable to leave the dust.
This pressing beneath Tài Mountain—
this is the Dao-body unable to leave the world.
Hence the sighs of *"tree too tall," "name too high."*

For those who wish to transcend the dusty cycle,
nothing surpasses embodying the Complete True Dao.
To embody the Complete True Dao,
nothing surpasses refining and ingesting the Golden Elixir.
What is precious is sudden awakening—
then the spirit and clarity naturally arise.
This is the Original Spirit aiding the Dao,
so heavy burdens may be removed,
shoulders’ loads may be set down,
and the Purple-Gold Gourd treasure
no longer manipulated by demons.

The traveler transformed into Old Complete True,
self-proclaimed immortal,
not only saving himself
but wishing to save others—
his magnanimity truly encompasses heaven and earth.

The claim of *"packing heaven"* is not baseless,
yet why cannot heaven truly be packed,
and only the request to *Nèzhā* borrow
True Wu’s black-embroidered banner from the North Heaven Gate,
to obscure the sun and moon of the South Heaven,
to deceive the two demons?

The sage intended another meaning—
thus setting this symbol,
to expose those who falsely claim immortality,
who use the River Chariot to transport water for brain-washing,
deceiving the world with gold and jade treasures,
while obscuring the true, empty nature of the Original Heart.

Those who falsely claim immortality
demand money upon meeting.
Greedy and deluded men
know only of refining gold and silver,
hoping to gain their methods—
even the most meticulous and nimble,
once encountering them,
willingly revere, believe, and submit,
not sparing true treasures,
fearing to be left behind in sincerity.

Though they do not rob in broad daylight,
they truly deceive in darkness.

The traveler transformed into a seven-*cùn* Purple-Gold Red Gourd,
resembling a human form.
The *Zhǎng Fǔ* records:
*"A *cùn* of land, a *cùn* of field—
enough to sustain life."*
The *Huáng Tíng Jīng* says:
*"A *cùn* of land—this is the face,
the space between the brows is the *cùn* used."*
Now it is *"seven *cùn*"*—
thus encompassing the middle field, lower field,
and connecting to the seven orifices.

The human body is also a Purple-Gold Red Gourd—
in measure, it can pack heaven.
If the Golden Elixir is not obtained,
it is but a false form—
a false gourd.
Without the true capacity to pack heaven,
it must resort to deceiving heaven with trickery.

*"Nèzhā treads the Wind-Fire Wheel"*—
comparable to the River Chariot;
*"True Wu’s black banner"*—
comparable to the Dark Water;
*"North Heaven Gate"*—
comparable to the Water Palace;
*"South Heaven Gate"*—
comparable to the Vertex;
*"Sun, moon, stars"*—
comparable to the two eyes.

*"Toss up the gourd, unfurl the black banner,
obscuring sun and moon"*—
comparable to transporting water upward to the vertex,
to brain-wash and close the eyes.

*"Heaven and Earth dyed black, the cosmos stained indigo"*—
is this mere empty talk?
Such methods are truly inking heaven and earth—
like standing on a perilous cliff over the苦海,
one slip, and you plummet into the abyss,
never to return.
Tremendous danger!
Tremendous danger!

「How much better to release the heavens,
and not engage in the trickery of transporting and obscuring—
to let the azure sky and white sun
shine forth with the light of true noon!

Alas, what of those cunning and clever fiends,
who take falsehood for truth as a means to sustain their families and prosper?
They lose their true nature and stray from their original heart—
how pitiable this is!

If readers mistakenly view the Two Demons’ *shifting of mountains* as external Dao deceiving the true,
or the Six Jian’s *transporting of mountains* as the primordial spirit aiding the original heart,
they are superficial in their understanding.

**Chapter 34**
*The Demon’s Clever Scheme Traps the Monkey King*
*The Sage’s Flight Fools the Treasure*

Wuyi Zi said: The *Yin Fu Jing* states:
*"Heaven has five thieves—those who perceive them flourish."*

If a person can perceive them and practice in reverse,
then the cosmos lies within their grasp,
and myriad transformations arise from the heart.
Heaven is the heart.
The five thieves are the five elemental natures inherent within the heart.
Each element manifests its own nature,
and they mutually harm and destroy one another.
My primordial *qi* is all stolen by them,
and the heart of heaven is thus ensnared.

In the passage, the Two Demons declare:
*"We possess five treasures."*
These are the five elemental natures.
If one perceives them,
while the heart discards all illusions,
and the body becomes as vast as the Great Emptiness,
then weapons become treasures;
if one cannot perceive them,
while the heart gives rise to stray thoughts,
and they mutually suppress one another,
then weapons and treasures turn into thieves.

The text concludes with the Sage saying:
*"You old fool, if you let your servants run wild,
you’ll be held accountable for failing to restrain them."*

Lao Jun replied:
*"This has nothing to do with me.
Such trials are the fate your disciples must endure.
Without this, they cannot attain true fruition."*」

Sun Wukong’s heart now understood those words and penetrated their true meaning.

The *"Jade-Gold Red Gourd"* symbolizes the **Li** fire—flaming upward, externally yang yet internally yin. Its fiery nature like a gourd, red in hue, embodies the **Wǔgōng** (Three-legged Crow) and the sun’s essence. The *"Mutton-Fat White Jade Flask"* symbolizes the **Kǎn** water—gentle and moist, externally yin yet internally yang. Its smoothness like jade, white in color, is the **Yùtù** (Jade Rabbit) and the moon’s purity. The *"Seven-Star Blade"* symbolizes the **Jiǎn** (Mountain) and **Duì** (Lake) meeting in metal, the nature of earth and water converging in breath. The *"Banana Leaf Fan"* symbolizes the **Zhen** (Thunder) wood and **Xùn** (Wind) wind, the clash of wind and thunder. The *"Shaking Golden Lasso"* symbolizes the **Qián** (Heaven, firm) and **Kūn** (Earth, yielding)—the two *qi* intertwining, long and short as they will, swaying uncertainly, the very essence of the central land. In form, it encompasses the eight trigrams; in substance, it belongs to the five elements. The mother and child demons each hold one treasure, each embodying its nature, hence their monstrous forms.

The lesser demon, lost in delusion, attempts to usurp heaven, thus losing control of its elemental essence. The blame lies with the celestial assembly for deceiving with falsehoods, unaware of recognizing falsehood as truth. Their error stems from their own missteps—still groping blindly beneath the earth after their failed attempt to usurp heaven, unwilling to abandon the false, fearing the easy loss of truth while clinging to the false.

The Pilgrim transformed into a fly, and the Buddha’s *intention-jewel* also changed with him—this is the true principle. **Kǎn** and **Li**, the roots of creation, give birth to all things; their movement is inevitable. In the demon’s body, they are demonic treasures; in the Buddha’s, they are Buddhist treasures. Even a fly’s body can contain them—how could this be mere empty talk?

The two demons misused **Kǎn** and **Li**, losing their true nature. In anger at the false pretenses of the celestial deceivers, they sought to exploit the *intention-nature* by force, compelling the primordial *qi*. Thus, they begged the Old Mother to obtain the *Shaking Golden Lasso*.

The *lasso* is two strands intertwined, never unified. *Shaking* signifies doubt and confusion in the mind, without certainty. The nine-tailed fox holds it, for foxes are prone to suspicion; nine tails symbolize chaos. The *Chāibā Mountain Tiger* and *Yǐhǎi Dragon* display their mistaken grasp of dragons and tigers, boasting of their supposed prowess in subduing beasts.

The Pilgrim secretly observed their foundation, striking down their strength and transforming their doubt—what is taken for truth may still be false, while what is false may yet be true. Knowing falsehood as false makes it true.

The Pilgrim took the guise of an old nurse entering the cave, and Eight Rules mocked him for exposing his tail, revealing the truth hidden within falsehood—something that cannot be entirely erased. The demon king sought to offer Tang Sanzang’s flesh for longevity, while the Pilgrim demanded to cut off Eight Rules’ earlobes for wine, exposing the urgency of discarding falsehood within falsehood. Both ears must listen keenly.

The True Person’s teachings are not idle; they are not mere objects of ridicule or jest. The Dao of the Primordial does not cling to form or sensation, nor does it fall into perception and hearing. Round and radiant, it bears no trace—neither thread nor particle.

The Pilgrim had no choice but to manifest and disperse, transforming into a crimson glow filling the cave—*gathered, it forms shape; dispersed, it becomes qi*.

As the *Vajra Unveiling* states:
*"If one seeks me through form, or calls me through sound,
That person walks the wrong path and cannot see the Tathāgata."*

Thus, those ensnared by form and sound remain prey to the tiger’s jaws, while those trapped by names and appearances are but hollow reeds.

When the Pilgrim used the golden lasso to snare the demon king, it became the demon’s own lasso binding its body—how could it escape its own trap? When the demon king used the lasso to snare the Monkey, it was demon confronting demon—how could it harm the Monkey’s slightest hair?

The two demons used the gourd to deceive the Pilgrim, calling him by name—this was seeking the Buddha through sound. Why not answer with false names to their delusion? The Pilgrim, in turn, called the demons from within the gourd—also using sound to deceive them, yet transforming falsehood into truth.

To break the golden lasso, a few strokes with a steel file suffice—wisdom manifests, and knowledge dissolves. To escape the gourd, a few shouts are enough—the physical form vanishes, and compassion pervades universally.

The golden noose tightens around the neck; the light behind it is still an illusion, yet liberation is still needed. The gourd’s darkness hides a treasure yet unrefined—urgent enlightenment is required.

Do not say the gourd belongs to its master by clever artifice—
Better to borrow hands to achieve what comes naturally.
In an instant, it rises—*that is me.*

Thus it is said:
*"Granted your schemes are cunning in a thousand ways,
Yet the gourd still bears the surname Sun."*

Sun Wukong—Wukong Sun. Forward and backward, inverted, all belong to the surname Sun.
Ah! From *"surname Sun"* one awakens to the mystery of sons and grandsons.

Taking **Kǎn** to fill **Li**, returning to the exposed primal *qi*—*"Catch a breath, and you’re off, disguised."*

Fools mistakenly guess this as the art of the bedroom.

---
**Chapter 35: External Paths Display Power to Deceive True Nature**
**The Monkey King Steals Heaven’s Treasure and Subdues the Demon**

A disciple of enlightenment says: The two young demons stole heaven’s treasures and became demons, turning the five treasures into five thieves. Sun the Great Sage stole heaven’s treasures and subdued the demons, turning the five thieves into five treasures.

The same heavenly treasures, the same act of theft—yet righteousness and evil are utterly distinct, depending solely on whether one cultivates or does not cultivate.

Gold, wood, water, fire, and earth—these are heaven’s treasures, and they are also humanity’s treasures. Heaven’s nature is humanity’s nature. If one exploits their nature one-sidedly, they mutually deceive and suppress each other: fire sees water as a thief, water sees earth as a thief, earth sees wood as a thief, wood sees metal as a thief, and metal sees fire’s force as a thief.

Each thief is a thief to its own nature, each nature is its own nature—yet they lose their true essence. When their natures are harmonized, they mutually generate: metal generates water, and the true yang within water can generate the yin of metal, while the yin of metal in turn can generate the yang of wood, and thus metal and wood intertwine as treasures.

Wood generates fire, and the true yin within fire can generate the yang of wood, while the yang of wood in turn can generate the yin of water, and thus wood and fire are both at their fullest as treasures.

They intermingle as parent and child, alternating as husband and wife, and together they attain their treasures. This is what is called "concentrating the five phases," reversing cultivation and transformation—just as **Nüwa** refined the five-colored stones to patch the sky.

The five-colored stones are earth. The method of cultivation relies entirely on the essence of earth. Earth has no fixed position, yet it governs the four seasons and embodies the central palace;

Fire, through it, does not flare,
Water, through it, does not overflow,
Metal, through it, endures long,
Wood, through it, does not wither.

Thus, *The Awakening to Reality* says: *"The five phases and four symbols rely entirely on earth."*

Metal, wood, water, and fire reside at the four corners,
And when viewed through earth, they are **external Dao**;
Earth dwells in the central palace,
And when viewed through metal, wood, water, and fire, it is **heart-monkey**.

Those who practice **external Dao** wield power
Are one-sided in their exploitation of nature,
Not the true method of **gold elixir**,
Hence they deceive the true essence.

Those who attain treasures with **heart-monkey**
Collect and harvest their treasures,
Obtain the true Dao of **gold elixir**,
Hence they subdue the evil demons.

Two key phrases, most clearly stated.

Readers who rigidly insist that **heart-monkey** is the human mind,
Or shallowly perceive **external Dao** as mere evil demons,
Fail to grasp their meaning.

The opening poem states: *"One’s original nature is round and bright, the Dao naturally flows through."*
A single phrase revealing the entire truth.

It further says:
*"Pure and turbid, how many times they turn with fate,
The eternal and the void, let them wander east and west."*
Illustrating the five phases’ cyclical transformations and the marvel of generation.

Thus it is said: *"This aligns with the Great Sage Sun’s profound Dao."*

The Great Sage Sun is also called **"Xingzhe Sun"**,
With a name that is ever-shifting—up, down, left, right,
Inverted without end—yet encompassing all phases.

He is the **central palace’s yang**,
For the Dao’s body is indeed such.

The **golden rope** of the previous section is also earth,
Yet it is vague and formless,
While the Great Sage Sun obtained its **pure steel’s true gold**.

Because of this true treasure,
He entered the gourd without dissolving,
For earth can quench flames;

Because of this true treasure,
He then obtained the gourd itself,
For fire meets earth and returns to its form;

Because of this true treasure,
He acquired the **jade purity bottle**,
For water sees earth and unifies in chaos;

Because of this true treasure,
He gained the **banana-leaf fan** and **seven-star sword**,
For metal and wood meet earth and intertwine;

Because of this true treasure,
He reversed the **silver angle** and **gold angle**,
For gold and silver meet earth and return to their roots.

The opening line thus declares:
*"The Great Sage Sun attained the true treasure of the demons."*
Linking past and present,
To show that the golden rope is the **true earth of the receptive female**.

This alchemy’s marvel of inverted control
Is akin to Nüwa’s use of earth to repair heaven.

Heaven is the ultimate yang,
Yet within yang there is true yin,
So Heaven One generates water and descends to nourish;

Earth is the ultimate yin,
Yet within yin there is true yang,
So Earth Two generates fire and ascends to blaze.

The **creative male** and **receptive female** are likewise.

The **Dao Ancestor of Highest Venerability**,
With the yang of the central palace,
Repairs the deficiencies of the creative palace,
And enlightens all ages.

The **"one stalk of immortal vine beneath the Kunlun Mountains’ foot, bearing this jade-red gourd"**
Is the supreme treasure for nurturing the elixir,
And must not be overlooked.

By reasoning, originally there were two—male and female.
Yet the female within the male is false,
While the male within the female is true.

The female cannot contain,
For the false cannot form the elixir;

The male can contain,
For the true can form the elixir.

*"Base upward, mouth downward"*
Is the logic of inverted correspondence.

When the silver angle is contained and shaken,
It is white gold entering the fire palace,
Transforming into one breath—

That is *"Gathered and returned to one place,
Turning into a pool of water."*

The progression now reaches **"King Wen of the Zhou, Confucius, and other sages"**
As the alchemists of old expound this principle,
Revealing its origin.

The silver angle contained within the gourd and transformed
Is not death,
But the demons returning to their true nature—
This is the act of **receiving life**.

Eight Precepts said: *"Do not weep, let your younger brother recite the ‘Receiving Life Sutra.’"*
Not mere idle words.

The method of elixir-making
First forges white gold as the elixir’s seed,
While the **gentle wind** aligns with fire’s rectitude at this moment.

Fire is not ordinary fire,
But the breath of **purple charcoal**—
The five phases’ natural transformations and their arranged operations.

The **Old Demon’s fury in his heart** reveals the timing of fire’s function.

Placing the **jade purity bottle** aside and using the fan and sword instead
Is the **gentle wind shaking the wood**, the **thunder emerging from earth**, and the **rising of the earth’s vigor**.

*"Gazing at the southern homocletic fire of Bing-Ding’s fan,
Only flames erupt from the ground—
Fierce and towering, scorching the sky and searing the earth"*
Marks the advance of the **yang fire**.

The Great Sage Sun avoided the fire,
Entering the **Lotus Flower Cave** to take the **ram-fat jade purity bottle**;
The Old Demon retreated to the **stone table**, drowsy and silent;
The Great Sage Sun quietly extracted the **banana-leaf fan**,
Revealing the retreat of the **yin symbol**.

The brilliance lies in the lines:
*"Causing gold and fire not to meet,
The five phases to disorder and harm the harmonious qi."*

Readers assume the **gold angle** is metal,
And **heart-monkey** is fire,
That metal and fire contend,
A common principle of suppression.

Yet they fail to see:
The **Monkey King hides gold and water**,
The **gold angle sits within wood and fire**;

「Water bears the **qi** of generating gold,
Fire bears the **qi** of generating wood;
Gold and wood share the **qi** of mutual support,
Wood and fire embody the **qi** of *jiéjì* [fulfilled/accomplished].

When gold and water intermingle, and water and fire are reconciled,
If gold and wood do not unite, then gold and fire do not contend,
And the lines—*"The five phases disorder and harm the harmonious qi"*—hold true.

Those who cultivate the **elixir** [丹 *dān*] seek not for gold and fire to contend.
When gold and fire contend, the five phases naturally flourish.
*"The Old Demon, defeated in battle, directly went to the Southwest to suppress the Dragon’s Retreat"*—
Seeking life from the source of my birth, pointing to *"Southwest gains a companion"* [得朋 *dé péng*];
Thus, he gained the aid of **Huli Seven** [狐阿七].

*"Huli Seven united as one, directly coming from the Northeast"*—
Returning to the source from where death comes, pointing to *"Northeast loses a companion"* [丧朋 *sàng péng*];
Thus, he fell to the **cudgel of Zhu Bajie** [猪八戒之钯 *Zhū Bājiè zhī yā*].

With both the **yang fire** and **yin symbol** exhausted,
The **gold angle** [金角 *jīn jué*] naturally returns to its origin.
The Great Sage Sun removed the **ram-fat jade purity bottle**,
Enveloped the Old Demon, and called out, *"Gold angle!"*
In response, it vanished without a trace.

Breath and resonance in harmony, no need for exertion;
*"Recalled the Seven-Star Sword, sweeping away all evil"*—
All were true uses of **earth** [真土 *zhēn tǔ*].

Seizing the moment unexpectedly,
Naturally unfolding the **Heavenly Mechanism** [天机],
Not through force, but the very essence—
This is the true meaning of *"gold and fire contending without harming the harmonious qi."*

The **Highest Venerable** [太上] transformed the **blind man** [瞽者 *gǔ zhě*],
Demanding the return of the five treasures,
And explaining the cause of their theft:
*"Without this, the **true fruit** [正果 *zhèng guǒ*] cannot be attained."*

He said that without seeing these five thieves,
One remains like the **blind man**;
But if one can reclaim these five treasures,
Then the **fruit** [果 *guǒ*] is secured.

Transforming thieves into treasures and enduring hardships,
This is the inevitable path of those who cultivate the **Dao** [修道者 *xiū dào zhě*].
What concern does the **Highest Venerable** have in this?

*"From the gourd and the jade purity bottle, two streams of **celestial qi** [仙气 *xiān qì*] poured forth,
Once again transforming into the two **gold and silver children** [金银二童子 *jīn yín èr tóng zǐ*].*
Returning to its original nature and essence,
All is but one **gold** [一金 *yī jīn*].

This is precisely—
*"Floating and elusive, all return to Tiāntóu Palace [兜率宫],
Free and unbound, ascending straight to Dàluó Heaven [大罗天]."*
The marvelous effect of the **gold elixir** [金丹 *jīn dān*] is such.

Aspiring cultivators must urgently seek the secrets within
The **Lotus Flower Cave** on **Flat-Top Mountain** [平顶山莲花洞].

Yet then—
The treasure of the **gold gourd** [金葫芦 *jīn hú lu*],
Which the **gold angle** [金角 *jīn jué*] governs,
Why did it instead manifest as the **silver angle** [银角]?

The treasure of the **ram-fat jade purity bottle** [玉净瓶 *yù jìng píng*],
Which the **silver angle** governs,
Why did it instead manifest as the **gold angle**?

The **gold** enveloping the **silver**—
True **masculine** [雄 *xióng*] transforming into false **feminine** [雌 *cí*],
A reversal in **elixir cultivation** [结丹 *jié dān*];

The **jade** enveloping the **gold**—
False **feminine** transforming into true **masculine**,
A reversal in **transcendence and rebirth** [脱胎 *tuō tāi*].

Alas!
The **Heavenly Mechanism** [天机] is nearly fully revealed.

The **Lotus Flower Cave** on **Flat-Top Mountain** [平顶山莲花洞]—
I once read Master Matteo Ricci’s *Explanation of the Form of Heaven and Earth* [《天地形说》]: Heaven’s body is a vast circle, and Earth dwells fixed at its center. Above, below, and on all four sides are human figures, their soles facing each other in perfect alignment.

For the **qi** of Heaven is clear and ascends, while the essence of Earth is turbid and descends. All around are Heaven’s dominions, so Earth must naturally rest at the core. The very center of Heaven becomes the very lowest point of Earth—thus all figures stand upright, balanced within.

This elucidates the profound truth of the **Dao/Way** of **Emperor Yao**, **Shun**, and **Xi He** [羲和] onward, a revelation truly surpassing all ages!

Calendrical calculations originate from Earth’s heart, yet through them the **Heavenly Mechanism** [天机] remains unexhausted—all this stems from the **soul’s luminous insight** [心之灵明神悟], does it not? Is this not the **soul’s embrace of Heaven and Earth** beyond measure?

Humans indeed possess the **gold gourd** that contains Heaven and Earth.

**Chapter Thirty-Six**—
The **monkey-heart** [心猿] subdues all entanglements,
Splitting open false paths to reveal the **bright moon** [月明].
**Master Treu-One** [悟一子] said: *The Journey to the West* expounds the **unspoken truths** of the *Yellow River* and *Lo River* [《河》、《洛》], clarifying the **marvelous Dao/Way of inverted yin-yang** [阴阳颠倒之妙道], and pointing to the **true path of cultivation** for all ages.

The earlier text concealed its meaning in veiled metaphors, leaving none unexpressed. Now I reveal the **essential core** of past **immortals and sages** [仙圣], taking the *Awakening to True Reality* [《悟真篇》] as proof, to transmit the **gold elixir’s** [金丹] true essence. This is no mere **Chan School** [禅门] misconception of emptying the **soul’s power** [性] through worship and scriptural pilgrimage!

A **clear mirror** [明镜] stills the waters,
A **radiant moon** [皓月] illuminates the **Chan heart** [禅心].
The ancients and moderns who speak of the **Dao/Way** call this the **sage’s attainment of the Buddha’s path** [圣修佛诣], and here its peak is reached.

Yet the **sage’s** so-called **"Divine"** [神] has depths beyond knowing,
And the **Buddha’s** so-called **"Fruit"** [果] is never truly absent.

「Abandoning the affairs of Laozi, to whom else shall I turn?
The upper section reveals Laozi’s **Five Thieves** [五贼] to subdue the **heart-mind** [心君], which is **Internal Alchemy** [内丹]. In truth, it is the very principle of **External Alchemy** [外丹].

The principle knows no distinction between inner and outer,
Yet the **elixir** [丹] has both inner and outer.
When the inner is established, the outer naturally follows;
When the outer is attained, the inner naturally completes.
Inner and outer, outer and inner—
Inner yet again outer, inner and outer sharing the same source,
Crushed into one seamless whole.

The **work** [功] spans beginning and end,
The beginning founds the end,
The end fulfills the beginning.
Again, the beginning is the beginning and end,
The end is the beginning and end.
Inner and outer, beginning and end—
Reversed and overturned, profound beyond measure,
Unspeakable in words,
The **sage’s** so-called **"Divine"** [神] and the **Buddha’s** so-called **"Fruit"** [果].

At the start of the chapter, the **Master** [师父] spoke fully of Laozi’s affairs,
Though it follows the previous text, it truly sets forth the next intent.
The practitioner says: *“Master, if one only subdues the nature and preserves the Divine, there is no need for further affairs.”*
This is the meaning of **still waters** [止水] and **Chan heart** [禅心].
If one can truly transcend affairs, what need is there for the elixir?
The **Three Treasures** [三藏] hope for long practice to reach the Western Paradise;
The practitioner laughs: *“You haven’t even left the outer gate yet!”*
Saying that by subduing the nature and preserving the Divine, one naturally attains the golden elixir,
This is like hoping for the Western Paradise while yet unstepping through the outer gate—
Hence the saying: *“Do not cling to it; simply let your heart-mind go free and advance forward—
The work will naturally complete itself.”*

“**Freeing the heart-mind**” [放心] means letting go of all attachments,
Yet it is truly the act of gathering the heart-mind without letting it go—
Freeing is the very act of not freeing.

“**Advance forward**” [前进] means that all worldly beings do not advance,
Only by retreating and secretly cultivating does one truly progress—
Retreating is the way to advance.

The work, when truly attained, must first manifest affairs,
Yet when it naturally completes itself, it is not forced.
These words carry deep meaning—
Do not read them as mere encouragement to rush blindly along!

When the **Emperor** [进敕] bestowed the **Precious Forest Monastery** [宝林寺],
The **Elder** [长老] nodded and said: *“Even the **scaled and shelled beings** [鳞甲众生] worship the Buddha,
Yet why would humans not practice the **Dao/Way**?”
He sighed, lamenting that the monastery had only the name of **Precious Forest**,
But lacked its true essence.

The **monk-officials** [僧官] struck the **laymen** [道人] lightly,
As the world does—no cause for surprise.
The practitioner shattered the stone lions,
Transmitting singularly and uniquely,
Startling the crowd and bewildering them.
*“It’s not convenient; you should move them away.”*
This can be seen as **perfect adaptability** [圆便],
Not an invention of Old Monkey—
It follows the method of **stealing the body and rebirth** [夺舍投胎].
*“If you don’t strike them, you’ll carry them in anyway.”*
Once the **stick and shout** [棒喝] has been given,
Though the **monk** [和尚] may turn back,
He remains bound to the **Two Vehicles** [二乘].
“**One bundle of poverty**” [一裹穷]—
A self-made affliction,
Lonely cultivation and rigid sitting,
A bundle of poverty within which no elixir forms,
Dishonoring the **Precious Dharma Jewel Monastery** [法宝珠林].

“**Four-bed platform**” [四张床]—
Master and disciple sharing the same couch,
Three families united,
The **Five Phases** [五行] gathered in harmony,
Only then does the **inexhaustible marvel** [妙赏不尽] appear.

On the **fifteenth day**, **pure yang** [纯阳] prevails,
The **Pre-Heaven Bagua** [先天八卦]—**Qian** [乾] Trigram—**three yang lines** [三阳爻].
The **thirteenth day**, **pure yin** [纯阴] prevails,
The **Kun** [坤] Trigram—**three yin lines** [□卦爻图略].

The **first three days** [初三日],
Kun conceives **one yang** [一阳] at **Geng** [庚] above,
The **Zhen** [震] Trigram—**two yin lines above, one yang line below** [上二阴爻，下一阳爻],
The **fire potency** [火候].
The **eighth day** [初八日],
Kun gives birth to **two yang** [二阳],
The **Dui** [兑] Trigram—**one yin line above, two yang lines below** [上一阴爻，下二阳爻],
The **front crescent** [前弦],
The **medicine and substance** [药物],
The **yang** [阳],
The **first eight** [一八].

The **fifteenth day** [十五日],
**Pure yang** [纯阳],
The **Qian** [乾] Trigram—**three yang lines** [三阳爻].」

On the **sixteenth day**, **Qian** [乾] generates **one yin** at **Shen** [申] above,
The **Xun** [巽] Trigram—**two yang lines above, one yin line below** [上二阳爻，下一阴爻],
The **fire potency** [火候].

On the **twenty-third day**, **Qian** generates **two yin**,
The **Gen** [艮] Trigram—**one yang line above, two yin lines below** [上一阳爻，下二阴爻],
The **rear crescent** [后弦],
The **medicine and substance** [药物],
The **yin** [阴],
The **two eights** [二八].

The *Cántóng* [参同] states:
*"Kàn-Lí* [坎离] are the **two functions of Qian and Kun** [乾坤二用].
Two without fixed positions, circulating through the **six voids** [六虚].
Coming and going are not fixed, above and below have no constancy."
Thus, the Sage adopts these **two eights** [二八],
And from them, **Kàn-Lí** [坎离] arise within—
This is called **"embracing One to contain Three"** [抱一函三].

The **secret verse** [诀] says:
*"Pre-Heaven **One Qi** [先天一气] transforms into **Qian-Kun** [乾坤],
**Gen-Dui** [艮兑] revolve at the **Zhen-Xun** [震巽] gates.
Only the **six voids** [六虚] generate wondrous efficacy,
**Kàn-Lí** [坎离] ebb and flow—**Dao** [道] holds supreme."

This is the **true utterance of the Moon’s brilliance** [月明之真言].
When insight is fully awakened, it is as if **taking the scriptures from the Western Heaven** [西天取经].

The **Sand Monk** further points out:
*"Gold in water"* [水中之金] is the **Five Phases converging** [五行攒簇],
Entirely dependent on **Earth’s correspondence** [全凭土配],
With the **three families united** [三家同会],
Only then does the **Sun’s fullness** [日圆] appear.
*"Water and fire intermingling each have their fate"* [水火相搀各有缘],
Encompassing the **mysteries of *Jìjiè*** [既济], **starting the work** [下手], and **warm nourishment** [温养].

The **Eight Precepts** further clarifies the **subtlety of waxing and waning** [圆缺不全之妙],
Which is the **unfinished secret** [不全之秘要] of *"The Moon emerges on the third day"* [三日月出庚] in *Cántóng*,
And the **true scripture of this very chapter** [本书本回真经].
It also indicates that after the **Moon’s fullness** [月圆],
One must fulfill **three thousand functions** [功满三千] to comply with **Heaven’s edict** [应天诏].

Each disciple expounds upon the **essential nature of cultivation** [本质阐发修炼玄机],
And thus the **entire oral transmission of the Golden Elixir** [金丹始终口诀] is fully revealed.

Yet fearing that one might **recite the *Heart Sutra* in vain** [空念《心经》],
While failing to grasp the **true scripture of Mahayana** [大乘真经],
The **Pilgrim**—through the fault of reciting incorrectly—
Fails to awaken to the **true scripture’s essence** [真经未取晓悟],
This is called **"splitting the side door to see the Moon’s intent"** [劈傍门而见月明意].

*"When the Moon reaches the Heavenly Heart,
The Phoenix comes to the water’s surface,
Such pure delight—
Few truly know its worth."*

The poet who composed this—
Did he understand?

---
**Thirty-seventh installment**
*The Ghost King Visits Tang Sanzang at Night*
*The Monkey King Transforms as a Child to Lead Away the Infant*

**Treasure One** [悟一子] says:
*"Above, the Moon’s body aligns with Pre-Heaven,
Yet the **wondrous efficacy of Kàn-Lí** [坎离之妙用] remains unseen.
From here onward, it clarifies how **evil masters fail to grasp the Moon’s intent** [月明的旨],
Misidentifying **heart and kidney as Kàn-Lí** [心肾为坎离],
Sealing the **tail-end orifice** [尾闾之穴] in vain,
Taking another’s child as their own,
Thus allowing **evil to occupy *Lí’s* position** [邪乘离位],
While the **true essence falls into *Kàn’s* domain** [真陷坎宫]."

The **case of the Wūjī Kingdom** [乌鸡国一案因果] is recounted to illustrate:
The **mother and child reuniting** [阿母婴儿，母子会合重逢]
Is the **true path of filling *Kàn* with *Lí*** [取坎填离],
The **Golden Elixir entering the mouth** [金丹入口],
The **correct method of reviving the dead** [起死回生之正道].

It must be clarified:
The **main theme—*"The Ghost King Visits the Three Sages"** [鬼谒三藏]—
Reveals that the **cause of falling into error** [失陷之由]
Lies in **mistaking the complete truth** [误认全真];
*"The Spirit Leads Away the Infant"* [神引婴儿]—
Shows that the **method of saving the whole** [救全之法]
Depends on **restoring faith between mother and child** [取信子母].

The **Ghost King** declares:
*"My home lies in the true west,
Known as the **Wūjī Kingdom** [乌鸡国]."*

The **three-legged crow, the black bird of day** [金鸡三足乌],
Is the **yin within the sun’s zenith** [日中之阴],
The **Heart Sovereign** [心君] itself.
When the **Sovereign’s fire rages unchecked** [君火亢炎],
Only **water can temper it** [非水不济].
The **complete truth arrives from the south** [南来全真],
Praying for rain to nourish the land,
And after long drought, rain falls—
**Water and Fire in Harmony** [水火既济],
Illustrating **Qian-Kun’s mutual response** [乾坤交感],
Where **Qian transforms into Kàn** [乾变为坎],
And **Kun transforms into Lí** [坤变为离].

Within **Lí**, the **void yin** [虚阴]—
**one yang line above and below, one yin line in the center** [上下各一阳爻，中一阴爻]—
Must be filled by the **true yang of Kàn** [坎中之真阳],
Only then is the **complete Qian essence** [乾体之真] restored.

If one **mistakes the false forms of the body’s heart and kidney** [一身心肾之假象],
And **clings to internal water-fire exchange as truth** [执水火内交为真],
This is **erroneously grasping the meaning of *"acquiring a companion in the southwest"** [西南得朋之义].

It is like the **true-west king** [正西国王],
Who **pledges brotherhood with the complete truth from Zhōunán Mountain** [结拜锺南山祈雨之全真],
Sharing bed and board,
**Seizing the true as false** [假夺其真],
While the **true is lost** [真者反陷].

**Kàn** [坎] is, in Pre-Heaven, the **true west** [本正西];
**Lí** [离] is, in Pre-Heaven, the **true east** [本正东].
The **true spirit of Lí** [离中真灵] resides in the west,
Thus the **true master of Kàn** [坎中之真主]
Is also the **true master of Lí** [离中之真主]—
They must not be **divided** [不得而二视之].

**Kàn** symbolizes a **well** [井].
