The **Kàn Hexagram** [坎卦]—
**one yin line above and below, one yang line in the center** [上下各一阴爻，中一阳爻]—
Its **upper and lower lines** [上下二爻] represent the **eight angles of the four directions** [八角四方],
Clear as **jade-like glass** [透如琉璃],
Hence it is said:
*"Eight-cornered glass well"* [八角琉璃井边].
*"Suddenly, ten thousand rays of golden light"* [忽起万道金光]—
This is the **true gold within Kàn** [坎中之一真金].
One can generate ten thousand—
Hence the **ten thousand rays** [有万道].
*"Pushed into the well’s depths,
Covering the well’s mouth,
Transplanting a banana tree above,
Transformed into my likeness,
Seizing the realm and territory."*

This allegorizes those who **mistakenly identify heart and kidney as Kàn-Lí** [谬认心肾为坎离],
**Sealing the tail-end orifice in vain** [空闭尾闾之穴],
While **inverting the true essence** [逆陷其真];
**Usurping the Sovereign’s *Tài* [泰]**
And **stealing its false pretenses** [窃行其假].

「When they speak of *"the City Deity"* [都城隍], *"the Dragon King of the Sea"* [海龙王], *"the Judge of the Eastern Prison"* [东狱阎君], *"the wine gathering"* [会酒], *"kinsmen and friends"* [亲友], *"brothers"* [弟兄], all these phrases depict their alignment with the **yin spirits** [阴神], sharing **qi** [气] in harmony, making clear that all four great elements [四大] within their being belong to **yin** [阴].

This is the discourse of the **Ghost King** [鬼王] paying homage and distinguishing between **evil and righteous** [邪正]. It reveals the **Prince of the Original Palace** [本宫太子], who is the **true yang’s direct lineage** [真阳之嫡脉], the **root of the savior** [救主之根裔]. Yet, he must seek guidance from the place where he was born from his mother [伊母生身之处], tracing the clues to fulfill his mission. If the mother and child are severed [母子隔绝], the child cannot fully express filial devotion or sincere communication [尽孝通诚], nor repay the mother’s kindness nor rescue the father from his predicament [报母恩而拯父难]. This illustrates the loss of **yin-yang’s primal order** [阴阳失其宗位], for how could one’s **true nature** [天性] remain uncorrupted?

*"Leaving behind a white jade* [白玉珪]*"—*
The **bi** [珪] symbolizes **sincerity** [信], and two **earthly elements** [二土] complement each other, signifying the **harmonious union of husband and wife** [夫妻合意同心], not mere outward pretense [外假模样] or inner emptiness [内无实用] that could achieve this. Hence it is said:
*"I shall entrust a dream to the Original Palace,
Instructing them that mother and child should unite in harmony,
So that you, master and disciple, may align in sincerity."*

This entire ghostly tale [鬼话] is but the **divine revelation** [天机].
When **Tripitaka** [三藏] stumbled and awoke in shock [忽绊一跌惊醒], he had just realized the truth within the dream [梦中方觉].
The **Traveler** [行者] declared:
*"Master, dreams arise from thoughts.
A heart filled with dreams, like old disciple’s single true thought,
Is solely to behold the Buddha—
No dream shall ever reach me."*

He spoke of dreams as **illusions of the unenlightened** [蒙昧不真], for the **true person** [真人] knows no dreams. Yet **Tripitaka** is a true person—how then does he dream?

In ancient times, **Xinxie** [心斋] visited **Lord Yangming** [阳明公], and sat as a guest. When asked:
*"If the true person knows no dreams, why did Confucius dream of Master Zhou?"*
**Lord Yangming** replied:
*"This is the very essence of a true dream."* [梦真]
Xinxie heard this in astonishment [愕然], then knelt and bowed, facing north [逐下拜，执北面礼].

The dreams **Tripitaka** experienced came from the **lunar realm** [论月中]. *"Ghost"* [鬼] and *"cloud"* [云] are but the **soul of the moon** [月魂]. This is the **true essence of the lunar dream** [梦月中之真], not a false one. Hence, the Traveler saw within the moonlight a **white jade bi** [白玉珪] indeed, and said:
*"This matter is true."*

Yet many doubt this, unwilling to act decisively. The Traveler took full responsibility, saying:
*"All lies with old disciple.
Just follow my lead, and it shall be done."*

This is the **Buddha’s promise** [佛祖所云]—*"I now guarantee your success,
And this extraordinary affair shall be fulfilled."* [我今为汝保任，成此希有之事]

The brilliance of decisive action lies in **first binding the infant** [先结婴儿].
Why is binding the infant not beyond the **Kàn-Lí* [坎离] *fulfilled* [既济] *Dao/Way* [道]?
He transformed the **red lacquered box** [红金漆匣], placing the **bi** [白玉珪] within—
Two **earthly elements** [二土] in harmony,
This is to summon the infant to witness the **secret teachings** [秘法].

Marvelous indeed!
*"The Great Sage transformed into a two-inch-long novice monk,
Hiding within the box"*—
A **strange transformation** [奇变] into its **complement** [偶], a **great into small** [大变小],
The **primordial and postnatal** [先天后天] have no fixed form—
With or without substance, they are ever-shifting in appearance [无定体，有质无质无常形].
*"This treasure within the box
Can foresee the past and future of one thousand five hundred years."* [能知一千五百年过去未来之事]
Is it not the **refined essence of the three-five* [三五] *cycle* [之精灵] *?* [耶]」

「The name **"Establish the Emperor’s Treasure"** [立帝货] is given,
Capable of founding the great principle of the world,
Yet causing the Emperor to emerge from **Zhèn** [震].
It transmutes the **treasure** [宝贝] into a **true person** [真人]—
Not the **I, Zhou, Huò, or Gé** [伊、周、霍、葛] of old!

The **Great Sage** [大圣] transformed into a **white hare** [白兔儿],
As the **moon’s spirit** [月魂], the **refined essence of true yang within yin** [阴中真阳之精].
Without this essence, one could not **bind the infant** [结婴].
There are **unfathomable yin-yang transformations** [阴阳不测],
Marvels of **divine transcendence and alchemical change** [出神入化之妙],
Thus the **Crown Prince** [太子] shot an arrow at the white hare,
And the **Great Sage** [大圣] dove into the **red box** [红匣].

When **yin moves**, it becomes **yang**;
When **yang stirs**, it turns to **yin**—
This is what is meant by **divine transformation** [神化].

The **Tripitaka Master** [三藏] spoke of **seeking scriptures in the Eastern Lands and offering treasures** [东土求经进宝],
The Crown Prince replied: *"The Eastern Lands are indeed exhausted beyond measure!"* [东土其穷无比。]
Why so? Though **Golden Master** [金公] was born in the East,
He was truly **a parasitic guest of the West** [实寄生于西].
The West is rich, the East is poor—
This is his natural state.
One must **clearly discern** [认得],
To summon him without letting him **drift away to other lands** [流落他乡],
Only then can **mother and child reunite** [母子相见],
And the **child repay the father’s kindness** [子报父恩].

Thus the **Tripitaka Master** [唐僧] said:
*"You have not avenged your father’s wrongs—
In vain you claim to be human!"* [你的父冤未报枉为人！]

The **Disciple** [行者] leapt from the box,
From a **three-foot-tall child** [三尺之童] to full growth,
All in an instant.
Past, present, and future,
Ancient and modern—
All beings, all things are thus.
By understanding the **principle** [理], one knows them all—
Why bother with endless calculations?

But if one can **recognize** [识得] the **lonely one** [称孤者] in the present,
Then **true insight** [真知] into the **ten thousand ages** [千万年] will be **burningly clear** [灼见],
And **fully comprehended without remainder** [已了彻无遗矣].

For the **human form** [人身] arises from the **interaction of Heaven and Earth** [乾坤交感],
Yet the **true father of one’s birth** [生身之真父] has already **fallen into the abyss** [失陷于坎].
The present body is but a **pure yin phantasm** [纯阴之假体].
All mistake it for reality—
They are all in a **dream** [梦中].
The Disciple could not help but **speak plainly and directly** [正色直指]:
*"The one who departed as the wind spirit—
That is your **true father of birth** [生身之老父];
The one now seated—
That is the **fully authentic** [全真] one who **prays for rain** [祈雨]."*

How **sharp and decisive** [斩绝明快]!
Yet alas—
The **bewildered** [迷人] do not believe,
Instead, they **mistake the one presenting the white jade** [白玉珪] *as*
The **deceiver of my treasure** [骗我宝贝之人]!

Beyond the **name** [名], there is another **name** [名];
Beyond the **body** [身], there is another **body** [身].
*"The white hare pierced by the arrow—
That is **Old Monkey** [老孙]."
*
If one recognizes the **white jade rabbit** [白玉珪] and believes in it without doubt,
Then one may **recite** [念] the **enactment of filial gratitude** [养育恩] and **avenge the wrongs done to one’s parents** [替亲报仇].

The **Immortal Master** [仙师] in this passage
Reveals the **Dao/Way’s profound mysteries** [道妙] line by line from the **true parents of one’s birth** [生身父母],
Hence the saying:
*"Ask your **country’s mother, the queen** [国母娘娘] a single word—
See how their **husband-wife affection** [夫妻恩爱] fares!
Just this,
And you shall know the **true from the false** [真假].*
*
This is **whispered counsel** [悄语], **gentle admonition** [低言],
A **secret safeguard of one’s life** [密保性命之事],
Truly **urgent and earnest** [叮咛切嘱]!

**Chapter Thirty-Eight** [第三十八回]
*"The Infant Disciple Questions the Mother, Discerning Right from Wrong"* [婴儿问母知邪正]
*"Gold and Wood Merge with the Mystic, Revealing False from True"* [金木参玄见假真]

**Master Ru Yi** [悟一子] said:
*"The opening verse of this chapter reads:
‘When you meet me, speak only of the **cause of birth** [受生因],
And you will be one who has **attained the assembly of the Thus-Come One** [如来会上人].’
*
It states that if one knows the **source of birth’s cause** [受生因] from whence it comes,
Then one knows the **method of immortality** [不死之方] is also **constructed** [造] therefrom,
Is it not **transcendent and supremely awakened** [超然大觉]?
One who has **attained the assembly of the Thus-Come One** [如来会上人]!

**Confucius** [宣圣] said:
*"How can one know **death** [死] if one does not know **birth** [生]?
Only by knowing **birth** [生] does one then know **death** [死]."*

**Han Yang True Person** [汉阳真人] said:
*"One must take the **corpse** [死尸] as the **living body** [生尸],
Do not **cling to the label of ‘birth’** [生门] and **deny the label of ‘death’** [死门]."*

**Master Cheng** [程子] said:
*"If one can **trace the origins** [原始],
And **understand the principles of birth** [知得生理],
Then one can **grasp the end** [要终],
And **know the principles of death** [知得死理].*
*
All speak of this same **meaning** [义].

The mind, when made pure and still,
Sees the Buddha in the dust of the world—
Ten directions gaze upon the descending **Mighty One**.

This is the **Way** of keeping the heart clean while the body remains in the world;
The Buddha is vast within the dust, not confined to the Western Paradise.

The body, undivided in self and other, reveals the **mysterious principle**—
This **Mighty One** descends from the void, untouched by names and forms.

As the *Avataṃsaka Sūtra* states:
*"Bodhisattvas belong to sentient beings;
Without sentient beings, all bodhisattvas would never attain supreme awakening."*
This is the meaning of the Buddha in the dust, seen by all ten directions.

*"To know the true master of today,
One must inquire of the mother who bore you in years past."*
This speaks of cultivating the **elixir** today, yet to grasp its true mystery,
One must delve into the origin of the mother who gave birth to you,
Only then will the truth be clearly understood.

As the *Awakening to Reality* states:
*"Urge you to seek the source of your birth-body,
Returning to the origin is the **Pharmaceutical King**."*

*"There is another worldly realm unseen by the world,
Each step a new beginning, each stride anew."*
This **teaching**, transmitted outside scripture, is rarely known by the world.
If one knows it and walks this path,
Each step blooms with fresh flowers—
Lotus after lotus unfolds.

As **Zhongyang True Person** said:
*"If you wish to leave secrets in the world,
Few are the true listeners."*

And the **Dan Jing** states:
*"One grain advanced, one grain refined—
Golden lotuses bloom, yet none recognize them."*

The verses here use symbols to reveal meaning—
What matters is transcending symbols to grasp the **meaning**,
And forgetting words to hold the **meaning**.

The tale of the **Princess**’ dream:
*"Remembering half, forgetting half,"*
For husband and wife reuniting are half true, half false—
How much more so in the realm of dream-death?

The forgotten half conceals a hidden meaning,
Only revealed later through the **Pilgrim’s** and **Eight Rules’** exploration of **metal and wood** mysteries,
Where truth and falsehood are discerned.

The **Prince** asks:
*"Mother, how deep was the love between husband and wife in the palace?"*
The **Princess** replies:
*"This matter remains unclear even in the underworld."*

*"Speaking of cold and warmth so starkly distinct,
With emotional ties severed—
One may perceive that true love is the **orthodox (正)**,
While separation is the **heterodox (邪)**.

This is entirely an empty illusion of **husband and wife**,
Yet falsely clings to lineage as a son—
**Suppressing the natural flow of Dao (天机)**,
**Defying the true nature of existence (真性)**—
What is more **heterodox** than this?

If one wishes to **correct the orthodox** and **remove the heterodox**,
They must first make **husband and wife, mother and child** believe in unity—
Only then can the **previous life** be saved,
Preventing its **degeneration and obscurity (沉沦埋没)**.

The **Princess** recognizes **White Jade Tablet (白玉珪)**,
**Unites it with the night’s dream (合诸夜梦)**,
And entrusts her son to **urgently invite the Holy Monk (圣僧)**,
To **discern the orthodox and heterodox (辨明邪正)**,
And repay his **filial virtue (父恩)**.

**Combining one tablet and two soils (总一圭二土)**,
**Uniting meaning and heart (会意联心)**,
From **death**, seeking **life (从死中求活)**—
Within **calamity**, **virtue emerges (害里生恩)**.

As in the *Awakening to Truth Chapter (《悟真篇》)*:
*"If one meets the killing intent and clarifies its reversals (若会杀机明反覆),
Only then does one know that within calamity, virtue arises (始知害里却生恩)."*

But—
*"To seek the Heavenly treasure (欲求天上宝),
One must use worldly wealth (须用世间财)."*

One must first **gather the Dao’s wealth (聚法财)**,
To **assist the practice of the Way (助道用)**.

**Sun Wukong (行者)** gathers a **wild wind of beasts (聚兽阴风)**,
And the **beasts of boundless measure (野兽)** respond in chorus,
With **great blessings (洪福)**,
Singing triumphantly as they return to the city—
This is the meaning.

Yet, those who practice this are as **numerous as cow’s hair (如牛毛)**,
While those who succeed are as **rare as rabbit’s horns (如兔角)**,
All because **truth and falsehood cannot be clearly discerned (真假未能确见)**.

The **discrimination between truth and falsehood (真假之辨)** lies in the distinction between **solitary cultivation (孤修)** and **mutual aid in practice (共济)**:
**Solitary cultivation** is **false** and difficult to fulfill,
While **mutual aid** is **true** and easily achieved.

If one does not **delve deeply with utmost care (精心穷究)**,
Nor **penetrate the profound mysteries (参透玄机)**,
Then they will **mistake the false for true**,
Or **mistake the true for false**—
**Erroneously acting**, they will never see the **true treasure (真宝)**,
How then can they **revive the dead and return to life (起死回生)**,
Or **remove the heterodox and restore the orthodox (除邪返正)**?

Thus, **Sun Wukong (行者)** has a matter in mind,
And **cannot sleep (睡不着)**—
After **consulting with his master (与师父计较)** and devising a plan,
He **delves into profound mysteries (深研几)**,
Revealing the **secret teachings of master and disciple (师徒传道之密旨)**.

**Sun Wukong** arrives at **Hui Gui’s (八戒) bedside** and calls for the **precious item (宝贝)**,
Saying, *"Let’s go steal it together."*
**Hui Gui** replies, *"I’ll go if it’s thievery."*
**Sun Wukong** says, *"Once we obtain the treasure,
I’ll buy it immediately."*
**Hui Gui** says, *"Then give the treasure to you."*
Both are **overjoyed (满心欢喜)**,
And on **clouds of boundless joy (纵祥云)**,
They **directly head to the banyan tree’s base and the well’s edge (径到芭蕉树下井边)**.

This is where **the metal father and wooden mother unite in meaning and heart (金公木母合意同心)**,
**Wood fully merges with metal (全木交并)**,
**Husband leads, wife follows (夫唱妇随)**,
**Plundering the Dao’s profound mysteries (窃天地之玄机)**,
And **stealing the vital breath of life from the killing intent (盗杀中之生气)**.

Those who **cultivate the elixir (修丹志士)**,
If they can **penetrate this profound truth (能于此处参透真妙)**,
Will have **the true treasure to act upon (真宝下手处)**—
As said in *"In the underworld’s gathering, none recognize it,
Only the banyan tree offers late-night contemplation (阎阳会上无人识，只与芭蕉作晚参)."*

**Hui Gui** descends into the well,
And suddenly sees the **Crystal Palace (水晶宫)**,
Asking the **Dragon King (龙王)** for the **precious item (宝贝)**—
This is the **symbol of filling the abyss (坎填离)**.

The **Dragon King** leads **Hui Gui** to the **Black Rooster King’s corpse (乌鸡王尸)**,
Pointing it out as the **precious item (宝贝)**,
And saying, *"**Sun Wukong** has the intention of **reviving the dead and returning life (起死回生)**,
Rely on you—**whatever treasure he seeks, he will obtain (要甚么宝贝都有)**."*

This **illustrates the elixir’s return and the reversal of yin and yang (寓丹道返还之妙，阴阳颠倒之用)**.
If one can **transform the killing intent into life-giving breath (转生杀之机)**,
And **practice it in reverse (逆而修之)**,
Then **calamity turns to fortune (灾中变福)**,
And **within harm, virtue arises (害里生恩)**—
As said: *"**The Five Phases (五行)** in their natural order are **hellish fire pits (法界火坑)**;
**Reversed practice (正行颠倒)** yields **seven treasures of the earth (大地七宝)**."*

**Hui Gui** **touches the corpse with one hand (一把摸着)**,
Yet **refuses to carry it out (不肯驼出)**.
**Sun Wukong** says, *"That is the **precious item (宝贝)**—
Why not carry it up?"*

**Hui Gui** **discerns the single stroke in the abyss (坎中之一画)** as **the essence of death (死质)** and not the **precious item (宝贝)**,
While **Sun Wukong** **discerns the true essence within the abyss (坎中之真主)** as **vital breath of life (生气)** and thus the **precious item (宝贝)**—
This is the **profound mystery of metal and wood in harmony (正金木相参之玄妙)**.

**Hui Gui** carries the **corpse back to the Monastery of Precious Treasures (宝林寺)**,
And says, *"My elder brother told me—
He can **revive the dead and return life (救得活)**."*

Was **Sun Wukong** truly **without intent (无意)**,
Yet **mocking him to take revenge (捉弄他报仇)**?

**The Great Sage (大圣)** has the intention of **reviving the dead and returning life**,
And the **Dragon King** had already spoken of it—
It is merely **borrowing Hui Gui’s actions (借八戒)** to **point out that the world truly has such elixirs (指世间实有起死回生之药)**,
Urging them to **seek it urgently (宜急早寻求)**.

If the **dead can be revived (死者尚可生)**,
Why fear that the **living cannot transcend mortality (生者不可仙)**?
This is **implicitly stated (隐然言表)**.

Ah! (吁！)"

The **imperial cap and robes** cannot halt decay—
Emperors and tyrants alike turn to dust.

If one does not refine the **Golden Elixir (金丹)**,
One’s life is but a ghost’s hollow abode.

---
**Chapter Thirty-Nine**
*A Single Grain of Elixir Obtained from Heaven*
*Three Years Later, the Old Master Revives in the World*

**Treasured Son** said: *"Zhuangyang True Person declared:*
*'Swallowing a single grain of elixir into the belly,*
*Only then does one know one’s life was originally from Heaven.'*
This speaks of the elixir being obtained from the **Yang world (阳世间)**,*
That life is self-made, not granted by Heaven.*

Yet the outline states *'obtained from Heaven (天上得)'*—
Is this not too distant, raising doubts in people’s minds?

But when it speaks of *'Heaven (天上)'*, it means **Heaven within humanity (人中之天)**,*
Not Heaven above (天上之天).

**Hui Gui** said, *"Master, do not believe him.*
He originally said one need not pass through the **Underworld (阴司)**—
In the **Yang world (阳世间)**, a physician can revive him."*

**The Great Sage** said, *"Let the Old Monkey try it in the Yang world."*
*"I shall now seek the **Venerable Laozi (太上老君)***
To beg for a grain of **Nine-Turn Reincarnation Elixir (九转还魂丹)**—
I shall certainly revive him!"*

For **Laozi’s wondrous Dao** exists within the **Yang world**,
And can be attained by all who seek it earnestly—
It is not in Heaven above, only waiting for those who find it.

**Lu Zu** said:
*"I hear people say they all seek me,*
*Yet they tread the world’s edges—no one truly finds me!"*

The **Immortal’s heart to save the world** surpasses that of mortals seeking salvation.
Yet mortals lack the **virtue and devotion** to receive salvation,
Refusing to **sincerely believe and hold firm in their hearts**,
Rejecting transformation, passing by **face-to-face with the True Ones**—
How can one force them to accept salvation?
All must await death before it is too late.

Speaking of this, one can only weep deeply!

**Hui Gui** guards the corpse and weeps—
*Is this the sorrow of **Bian Que’s lament (卞璞)**?*
*Or the pity of **Chu Fu’s grief (楚覆)**?*
*Or the mourning of **Chu Lin’s despair (锄麟)**?*
*Or the lament of **the collapsing city (崩城)**?*
*Or the wail of **Changsha’s grief (长沙)**?*

*Man’s life not yet ended, yet his heart already lost—*
*Oh, Heaven!*
Within a single cry, **yellow paths and black roads** intertwine,
Encompassing boundless suffering in the world’s salvation!

When the sorrow reaches its peak, those who hear shall surely weep—
How much more shall the **Elder’s heart ache with tears!**

**The Great Sage** arrives at **Li Hentian (离恨天)**, **Duosuo Palace (兜率宫)**.
**Laozi** instructs: *"The boys who guard the elixir,*
*Be cautious—thieves come to steal again!"*

When **The Great Sage** borrows the elixir and refuses to give it,
He turns to leave, but **Laozi** chases after him.
For the **Golden Elixir** is a **stolen treasure of transformation**—
Its presence or absence depends not on **Laozi’s stinginess**.
Fearful of theft, he must give it,
Yet giving it is the same as stealing—
The thief’s cunning is beyond all mortals’ sight or knowledge.

**The Great Sage** calls, *"Sha Monk, fetch water."*
**Hu Po** stirs the mixture in her voice.

He spits out the **Golden Elixir** into the corpse’s belly.
**Tripitaka** says, *"If one gains a human’s breath of life, it will suffice."*
**The Great Sage** exhales a **"huff"** of pure **qi** into the throat—
*"A loud sound—then the king’s **qi gathered, his spirit returned**."*

For the **Returning Elixir** has no form—
Without a breath of pure **qi**, it remains unseen.
*"Qi gathered, spirit returned"*—
This is when **metal returns to its original nature (金来归性初)**,
Only then can it be called **Returning Elixir**,
And the old king returns to his kingdom.

The **Water-Clothed Emperor** emerges from the **Kan Palace (坎宫)**—
Many are astonished, so **The Great Sage** clarifies:
*"This is the **Black Cock King (乌鸡国王)**, your true master!"*
He instructs the king to don **Daoist robes**,
Willing to ascend to the **Western Heaven**—
Yet why does **The Great Sage** then say,
*"You need not go to the Western Heaven—
You shall remain your emperor!"*

For a ruler who attains the **Dao in office** can
Practice the **Way of Yao and Shun (尧舜之道)**,
Transform the world, accumulate **virtue and deeds**,
Passing them to future ages,
Saving countless lost souls eternally—
This surpasses **Wei Fu’s merit and deeds a thousandfold**—
Why seek the **Western Heaven** again?

This passage’s poem reveals what *Awakening to Reality (悟真)* did not,
And transmits what the **scriptures** did not—
Yet readers dismiss it as idle chatter,
Equating **Heaven’s secrets and sacred instructions** with vulgar speech,
For they lack true guidance from a true master.

As the opening line states:
*"In the West, the secret is found—seek the True One."*
If one has not obtained the secret,
Even if a true treasure is before them,
How can they truly perceive it?

Next:
*"Metal and water harmonized—now refine the spirit."*
**Metal (金)** is the **Public (公)**, **Wood (木)** is the **Mother (母)**—
Their union forms the **elixir’s head**—
This is the shared meaning across countless scriptures.

If one has not obtained the secret,
They may mistakenly take *"harmonized"* as **alchemical union with a woman (闺丹御女之术)**,
Falling into heresy—
How then can they attain **Suchness (真如)**?

*"The elixir’s mother bears only confused dreams,"*
Meaning the **Ghost King’s dream**—
Half of it is not truly remembered.

Yet the elixir truly has a **Mother**,
And the Mother truly bears **confusion**—
Yet she conceals this mystery from her.

As it says:
*"The infant forever laments his parasitic body,"*
Meaning the **Quanzhen sect’s usurpation**—
The **Crown Prince** is the **parasite**,
Illustrating that the **Great Dao** has an **infant**—
Yet it is not empty.

Yet the infant truly has no form,
And the infant truly has a **parasitic body**—
This is the elixir’s profound mystery.

As it states:
*"One must seek the original master at the well’s bottom,"*
Meaning **Hui Gui’s descent into the well** and return with the **Ghost King**—
Illustrating **filling the **Kan (坎)** with **Li (离)**.*

Yet the **original master at the well’s bottom** has no form—
And the original master truly has a form—
Only those who seek shall find it.
And only by seeking through others can the elixir be perfected.

As it says:
*"One must also pay homage to Laozi in Heaven,"*
Meaning **The Great Sage’s** borrowing of the **Returning Elixir** from **Laozi**—
This implies that **elixir refinement must follow Laozi’s teachings.**

「Yet the **Laozi** is not in the **Heaven of Heaven (天之天)**, but in the **Heaven of Man (人之天)**.
*"Still one must pay homage"*—
This means bowing in reverence and returning,
Seeking from the **Heavens (天)**, then one may obtain the elixir.

It concludes with:
*"Awakening to the emptiness of form and returning to one’s true nature,*
*Truly the **Buddha** saves those with karmic ties.*
Meaning, after attaining the elixir,
One may perceive the nature and illuminate the mind,
Realizing **form is emptiness**, emptiness is form,
Returning to one’s original nature as void,
Then the **Buddha** may save those with karmic ties—
Seeing the **Buddha** is the **Immortal Sage**, the **Immortal Sage** is the **Buddha**.

Those with a predestined **Immortal Sage** connection,
Who can penetrate this verse,
The **alchemical elixir’s** profound secrets are complete—
Even **shelves of sacred scriptures** are no longer needed.

The **Master and Disciple** summon the **King’s** deposition,
The **Demon King** vanishes at the sight of the sky—
All recognize their **former master**,
For *"the true essence now resides in the Yellow Gold Hall (黄金室),*
*a single spark of wisdom forever departs not"*—
This is so.

The **liberation** comes not from the **Underworld (阴司), the Heavens (天), future lives (来生), or other realms (异世),**
But from one’s own **self (本身)** and the **manifest world (阳世)**.

In the following text, the **Demon King** is defeated—
If he were to **transform his guise** and still appear as the **King’s** form,
Would one not be unable to distinguish him?

Yet how does he change to resemble **San Zang (三藏)**,
So that the **Tight-Fitting Spell (紧箍咒)** can reveal him?

The **Immortal Sage** speaks metaphorically of the **original master’s** true and false nature being fixed,
Yet the **Master’s** transmitted secrets may vary.

If one encounters two **Masters**,
And cannot discern who is true and who is false,
Unable to distinguish and mistakenly takes the wrong one as genuine—
This would harm the true one.

Thus, the **verification** of the **living principle (活儿)** must be precise—
Only then is it the **true secret transmission**;
If one **blusters without verification**, it is false teaching.

**Sun Wukong** leaps higher,
Seeking **elevated insight** and **direct contact** with the **true principle**.

**Manjusri** holds the **Mirror of Demon Illumination (照妖镜)**,
Fixing the **Green Lion’s** demonic form—
*"By the **Buddha’s** decree, to avenge the grudge of the water calamity,"*
Meaning those who have suffered harm all mistakenly recognize their own **karmic sins (孽)** as fabricated.

*"This is a castrated lion—*
*It cannot defile purity."*
This refers to those who practice **solitude in the **Dharma of Emptiness (空门)****.

The **lion** is the **Master**.
The **Green Lion** is the **pretender Master**—
A **false Master** masquerading as the **true Master**,
How demonic! How tragic!

Yet in this world, there are many **castrated lions**—
How I wish **Manjusri Bodhisattva** would swiftly bring the **Mirror of Demon Illumination** to seize and remove them!

The **Mirror of Demon Illumination** is the **discriminative wisdom** that perceives others.

---

**The Forty-First Chapter: The Infant’s Play Disturbs the Zen Mind**
**The Monkey’s and Horse’s Knives Clash with the Wooden Mother’s Void**

**The Sage’s Disciple** says:
These three verses together reveal that,
After attaining the elixir,
One must fully perceive the nature and illuminate the mind,
Ascend to **highest clarity (上彻)** and descend to **lowest tranquility (下梧)**,
Sweep away the **six desires (六欲)**,
Practice **meditation, insight, and wisdom (禅定慧)**,
Face the wall in **non-action (无为)**,
And approach **transformation into the divine (神化)**.

First, it recounts **Sun Wukong** calling the **Daoist** to don his original attire,
Holding the **white jade staff (白玉珪)**,
Ascending the hall to proclaim himself **sovereign**—
This is the **Great Concealment (大隐)** not hindering residence in the court,
As the **wind stirs the world (风动天下)**,
And blessings extend to all people.

Then he declares:
*"I still act as my own **monk (和尚)**,
And go to cultivate **meritorious deeds (功德)**."*

This means that **laymen who attain the elixir (韦布之士)**,
If **greed, anger, and delusion (贪、嗔、痴)** remain unchecked,
And their **practices and virtues (功行)** are incomplete—
This is **cultivating life, not nature (修命不修性)**,
Also a **stubborn Immortal Sage** stuck in **deluded paths (滞迹)**,
Hard to transcend the **Three Realms (三界)**.

As the **Song of the Divine Elixir (敲爻歌)** states:
*"Only cultivating the **Master’s** nature, not the elixir,*
*The endless kalpas turn in vain—one never enters the **Sage’s** path.*
*Clinging to the **Dharma of Life (命宗)**,*
*Lost in the **Master’s** nature—*
*Like a mirror without reflection,*
*One’s face has no fixed image.*
*Lifespan equal to Heaven and Earth,*
*A foolish man with no mastery,*
*Yet holds wealth like a thief without true ownership."*

The **Immortal Sage** intentionally unleashes the **evil fire (邪火)** of **Hong Haier (红孩儿)** and the **filthy water (孽水)** of **Hei Shui Niao (黑水鼍)**,
To teach one to awaken to **true understanding**.

**Huiyan Sage**’s poem says:
*"There is a thing that precedes Heaven and Earth,*
*Formless, originally still and boundless.*
*It can be the master of all phenomena,*
*Yet does not wither with the four seasons."*

The **Dharma of Life (命)** is the **true nature (性)**.
**Nature** has **good, none evil**,
Yet the **mind** cannot be without **partiality and completeness**—
This is the **post-heavenal qi’s** purity and turbidity.

Thus, to **fulfill nature (尽性)**, nothing surpasses **dying to the mind (死心)**;
**Dying to the mind** means **dying to the mind that harms nature**.
To **die to the mind**, nothing surpasses **forgetting the contrivances (忘机)**;
**Forgetting contrivances** means **forgetting what disturbs the mind**.
To **forget contrivances**, nothing surpasses **nurturing qi (养气)**;
**Nurturing qi** means **nurturing the qi that moves the mind**.

**Hong Haier (红孩儿)** is the **innocent child’s heart**.
The **heart** is the **fire repository (火藏)**,
With **yang quality** and **yin nature**,
Externally bright, internally dark.
When **flame ascends (炎上)**, anger surges to the heavens;
When **first ignited (始燃)**, the **latent contrivance (伏机)** lies within.

*"Gathering fire-qi, it soars straight to the ninth sky,"*
This is **anger**.
*"Naked body, no clothing, dangling from the tree’s tip,"*
This is the **latent contrivance**.
Its **sudden rise and fall, ever-changing and unpredictable**,
Holds the **deceitful mind (昧心)** that plays with **true principle (正)**,
Desiring to **overthrow the enlightened wisdom (明眼)** that guards the **true principle**—
This is the **true contrivance**.

The phrase *"wasting one’s mental efforts"* is the **demon’s** confession.

The three **disciples** each grasp their weapons,
As if ready to strike—
The **Elder** rages at the **monkey’s** demonic tricks,
And in fury **seizes the horse** to scold.

All **portray** the **stimulated mind** in **anger**,
Disturbing the **Zen mind**.

*"Gully of the withered tree,"*
Wood dried, fire **flares**—
Tracing the **mind-demon’s** origin where its power thrives.
*"Red in hundreds of thousands,"*
Fire **intensifies**, color **burns bright**—
Describing the **mind-demon’s** rampant might.

Feigning **suffering from calamity and capture** to seek rescue,
And falsely claiming **lands, kinfolk** to offer **bribes**—
All are **exaggerations** of the **mind-demon’s** ever-shifting **deceitful schemes**.

**Bajie** wields the **staff of precepts (戒刀)** and cuts the **rope** to free the **demon**,
Unable to **perceive the mind** and thus **break precepts** to **free the mind**.

The **Elder** commands the **child** to **ride the horse** and take it away,
Yet **has not subdued nature** and thus **reluctantly allows the horse to follow its nature**.

*"Do not let the two monks carry it,"*
*"I am glad to carry it myself,"*
The **fire-demon** laughs and **recklessly subdues the gold**.

*"Only three catties in weight,"*
*"This frame is so light,"*
The **gold-demon** is **manifest yet secretly harbors fire**,
A **confused yet enlightened** state where **evil and true principle** persist through time.

The ancient poem thus states:
*"When Dao and virtue tower high, the demonic miasma rises high,
For the mind’s essence is inherently still—yet from stillness arises malevolence.
The Mind-Lord walks upright in the Middle Way,
Yet the Wood-Mother, dull and misguided, strays beyond and falls into chaos.

The Thought-Bird speaks not yet harbors amorous cravings,
The Yellow-Crone utters no words yet frets with anxious heat.
When rogue thoughts gain sway, they bring only fleeting joy,
For in the end, they dissolve from the very place where virtue was rooted.*

It speaks of how when the Middle Way is disturbed by agitation,
One cannot remain steadfast—thus stillness breeds malevolence.
The Mind-Lord is inherently upright,
Yet when fire stirs, the Wood-Mother falters—unable to grasp true principle, that is *"straying beyond and falling into chaos."*
Like the pulse of the Yin and Yang, the two chaotic paths,
Not guided by the Middle Way.

When lost, the Thought-Bird no longer obeys the Mind-Lord,
And amorous cravings arise—when cravings stir, the steadfast virtue is disordered,
Bringing upon itself anxious heat.

Only when rogue thoughts are rooted out from the place of virtue
Can one attain true stillness—stillness within movement,
Movement within stillness—like the steadfast virtue itself.
Then rogue thoughts have no power to run rampant.
This poem elucidates the core principle of the outline: *"Monkey-Horse-Staff-Gui-Wood-Mother-Empty."*
It is the true peril of a disordered mind.

When the mind is disordered, unable to remain steadfast,
The Monkey’s and Horse’s gold and water,
The Staff’s and Gui’s two soils,
The Wood-Mother’s wood and fire,
All lose their true nature and become empty—
That is the meaning: *"Where fire arises from wood, disaster will certainly strike."*

*"The Great Sage’s heart brims with resentment,"*
Steadfast virtue disrupted by movement;
*"That demon’s heart ignites with fury, stirring a whirlwind, hurling sand and stone,"*
Movement without steadfast virtue.

The Master’s traces vanish—
The mind is obscured, and nature falls into confusion.

The Pilgrim and Bajie confer, each parting their ways—
The mind is disordered, and the Five Phases become empty.

Sha Wujing says:
*"It has a beginning but no end."*
It means one can cultivate the vital breath (命) but not the nature (性).

Yet those who can truly begin and end are entirely reliant on the Thought-Soil (意土).
When the Thought-Soil is sincere, the Mind-Lord stands upright,
And delusion can be dispelled.
Sha Wujing is the Thought-Soil.
Thus the Pilgrim says:
*"Since the virtuous younger brother has such sincere resolve,
We shall still go in search of that demon,
To rescue the Master."*

The Great Sage’s heart burns with true anguish—
The Thought-Soil is sincere, and the Mind-Lord stands upright.

*"Transforming into three heads and six arms,"*
Three of Heaven’s, six of Earth’s—
Realigning the cosmos, fixing the upper and lower positions—
Steadfast virtue.

*"Strike eastward one path, strike westward another path,
And strike forth a band of impoverished gods."*
Ah!

Ah, wondrous indeed!

For truly, sincere intent must first attain knowledge—
to fail in attaining knowledge while striving for sincerity is folly, not sincerity.
How then could one clarify the heart and perceive the nature?

Thus the virtuous seeker values profound inquiry into subtle changes,
exhausting the divine to fathom transformations,
so as to exhaust their variations.

*"Strip one layer, hang one layer,
Pants without a crotch, trousers without a mouth."*
The utmost exhaustion—
to illuminate exhaustion by probing its essence,
and to exhaust its transformations utterly.

*"Six hundred *jie* drills piercing the mountain,
Encompassing thirty mountain deities,
Thirty earthly deities."*
Speaking of the Earth’s circular expanse,
vast and broad, six hundred *jie* in measure.

This is as the *Parameters of the Mysterious Unity* says:
*"Six-five, the receptive bearing,
Binding the beginning and end,"*
*"Sixty folds gathered on one axle."*
For the Earth thrice generates fire,
capable of piercing upward with fiery heat—
the *Li* hexagram’s symbol of clarity and dissolution.

When it follows Heaven’s bestowal,
it harmonizes its nature and nurtures all things;
When the Earth’s fire is excessive,
it distorts its nature and scorches all living beings.

The deities lament:
*"They grind our heads smooth,
leaving no incense, no paper—
no blood offerings at all.
They demolish our shrines,
strip our robes,
and leave us no peace."*

What harm is this but the rampant fury of fire’s nature?
Like a greedy official’s tyrannical blaze—
cruel and oppressive—
he plunders the people’s sustenance,
strips the earth bare.
Their hearts and their harm are one and the same.

*"Gutted-tree ravine, cloud-cave flames"*—
this describes the scorching inferno,
wooden fire raging, its smoke blinding the sky.

They speak of their parents—
the Bull Demon and the Rakshasa,
originally demonic,
refined in the Fire Mountain’s *sanmei* practice—
a perverse *sanmei*,
the extreme of evil,
not the true, upright *sanmei* of enlightenment.
They are called *"Holy Infant King"*—
infant yet self-sacred,
infant yet self-enthroned,
infant yet self-augmented—
merely ignorance incarnate.

Truly, *"Before refinement, the infant’s demon-fire prevails,"*
urgently requiring *"the Monkey-Heart and Wooden-Mother to uphold it."*
How terrifying, how perilous!

---
**Forty-first Chapter: The Monkey-Heart Defeated by Fire, the Wooden-Mother Captured by the Demon**

A sage of old said:
*"To let emotion return to its nature,
first teach fire to retreat within the heart.
Two forces merge as one essence—
golden elixir everywhere."*

Again he said:
*"To preserve longevity, first restrain desire.
If desire-fire does not falter, the spirit steadies itself.
Wood returns to fire, yet does not turn to ash—
if one restrains desire, life extends."*

For emotion arises from nature,
and wanders beyond virtue or vice—
all driven by fire’s transformations.
Without fire, nothing is born;
without fire, nothing is extinguished.

Thus fire’s power is most wondrous—
for good, it is potent;
for evil, even more so.

Nature is its root;
the heart, its dwelling;
the will, its trigger;
*qi*, its manifestation.
*"Most vast, most rigid,"*
filling heaven and earth,
unassailable.

If one nurtures *qi* rightly,
the heart remains undisturbed,
and nature steadies itself—
harmonizing with the Dao.

Mencius spoke of *"direct nourishment, vast and unharming"*—
this is adjustment, rectitude, and stillness—
the true essence of *sanmei*.

To preserve the heart and nurture nature
is to serve Heaven.
Heaven’s lifespan is unchanging—
this is the foundation of one’s fate.
Gathering virtue brings forth the elixir;
following the natural order receives its rectitude.
The Dao of the Golden Elixir is now fully revealed.

Ah! This Dao was nearly exhausted by Mencius.

The immortal master’s treatise
exposes those who harm the heart by failing to nurture *qi*,
thus fully elucidating Mencius’ chapter on *"nurturing qi."*

Zhuangzi said: *"Calmness nurtures *qi*."
Mencius taught that *"not forgetting, not assisting"* is the proper way—
both emphasize cultivation before disturbance arises.
But once *qi* is aroused and forcibly suppressed,
this is already a step behind.

The opening verse holds the crucial secret of proper nurturing:
*"Forgive all wrongs in an instant,
ignore gain and loss alike.
Conceal or reveal—let fate decide,
eat when hungry, drink when thirsty.
The spirit, still and serene, remains ever quiet;
if deluded, demons will intrude.
The Five Phases invert in the Zen halls—
when wind stirs, cold seizes."*

The meaning is clear—
no need for further explanation.

This is *"clarifying the heart, seeing nature,"*
where all attachments dissolve,
leaving not a thread behind.
Serene and forgetful,
quiet and unassisted—
this is the true nurturing of *qi*.

The final two lines warn:
If one cannot remain serene,
cannot forget or assist,
even in the Zen halls,
encountering scenes will stir the heart—
and this is not true nurturing.

Fire uses smoke as its messenger;
*qi* takes anger as its form.
Thus Mencius used the examples of She and Yi’s *qi*-driven courage
to illustrate its harm;
the immortal master used the Red Boy’s demonic *qi*
to depict its malevolence.

Fire is *qi*;
smoke is anger—
their meaning is one.

*"Five swift chariots"*—
light and easily agitated.
*"Pressing Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth"*—
fire governs the Five Phases,
just as the heart governs the Five Organs,
and anger governs the Seven Emotions.
As the verse says:
*"All generation and transformation stem from fire,
fire pervades the boundless sky, bringing life to all."*

*"The demon lost the battle,
then pounded his own nose in defeat,
spouting flames from his mouth,
thick smoke from his nostrils,
and fiery sparks from his eyes."*
All depict his *qi* erupting,
shaking his heart.

Seeing him strike his own nose, bleed,
and declare victory by sealing the door—
this reveals his unchecked arrogance,
his reliance on fearlessness as strength,
exposing his *qi*-driven fury.

Eight Rules exclaimed:
*"This wretch is shameless, unashamed!"*
Again: *"He unleashes such merciless fire!"*
Again: *"No hope!"*
Again: *"No justice—he sets the flames!"*
A true portrayal.

Eight Rules panicked,
abandoning the Pilgrim,
unwilling to engage further—
unable to align with righteousness and the Dao, he faltered.

Sand Monk sought victory through the theory of *"mutual generation and conquest,"*
using Water to subdue Fire—
but this failed in principle,
forcing suppression where harmony was needed—
a forced imposition like Zhi’s.

The Pilgrim sought rain from the Eastern Ocean,
and the Dragon King sprayed water on the flames—
like the Song scholar’s desperate attempt to coax the shoots—
*"Pouring oil on fire,
the more he doused, the fiercer it burned."*

Not only was it useless,
but it *"attacked the heart with fire-qi,
driving the Three Souls from their dwellings."*
Then came:
*"Qi choked his chest, his tongue grew cold,
his spirit scattered, his life abandoned."*
The shoots withered.

Eight Precepts and Sand Monk made the Pilgrim *"sit cross-legged in meditation, practicing the massage-Dhyāna technique."*

*"In a short while, his qi passed through the Three Passes,*
*turned at the Bright Hall,*
*burst open the orifices,*
*and he called out: ‘Master!’"*
Sand Monk replied: *"Brother, you were born my master—*
*even in death, you remain in my words."*

There must be purpose in this,
yet do not expect immediate results—
keep the heart undistracted.

*"Together they sat beneath the pine grove,*
*and in a short time,*
*his spirit settled, his qi harmonized."*
Thinking of *"invoking Guanyin Bodhisattva"*—
this was the gathering of virtue in action,
gradually entering the subtle realm of nurturing the self.

Yet gathering virtue is how one nurtures the qi,
and understanding speech is how one gathers virtue.
Unable to discern speech,
one fails to grasp the truth—
true and false become indistinguishable,
and actions in motion or stillness lose their proper measure,
leaving no path for virtue to gather.

The demon revealed the *Ruyi* skin-bag
and lured Eight Precepts,
*"transforming into a false Guanyin to await him."*

The *Ruyi*—
born from his own mind;
the *"false Guanyin"*—
emanating from his words;
the *"skin-bag"*—
a deceitful utterance.

Words may be deceitful, lustful, perverse, or evasive,
but we focus on deceit,
for it most clearly obscures the mind—
and one example suffices for the rest.

Eight Precepts, unable to distinguish true from false,
*"saw the image and took it for a Buddha,"*
believed the deceitful words,
and was stuffed into the bag—
unable to discern speech, he was deceived,
and though he grasped at virtue, it failed to gather.

The demon said: *"With your eyes wide open, you still don’t recognize me!"*
—revealing his own ignorance of his own deception.

Eight Precepts cursed from within the bag:
*"You’ve schemed every way to trick me into eating—*
*I’ll make sure you suffer the heavenly plague!"*
His words, born of malice, only harmed himself,
for he truly invited ruin upon his own nature.

The Pilgrim endured the pain and entered the demon’s cave,
daring not to confront him directly,
*"and transformed into a ‘melting-gold bundle’ to cast down."*
This transformation’s subtlety
nearly defies recognition.

For the mind is a fire-hiding place—
one must not let it flare upward.
The character *bao* (包) carries the radical of *bao* (包),
and though enclosure may seem profound,
it ultimately harbors two kinds of discomfort.
To cast down the bundle,
to abandon enclosure entirely—
what liberation!

Thus, he transformed into a bundle and cast it down,
to extinguish the flame.

*"Melting-gold"*—
the image of fire refining gold.
Ancient seal script for the character *xin* (心) was simply an inverted *"fire"* (火),
not enclosed but made to submit downward—
just as the Pilgrim *"cast down the bundle,"*
and as before, the meaning of *"letting go of the heart."*

Again, he transformed into a fly to scout ahead,
not first rescuing Eight Precepts
but following the Six Generals—
this was cautious, silent observation,
discerning the root without confrontation,
temporarily easing tensions to restrain its outbreak.

This action already subtly penetrated the *sanmei* [三昧].

**Chapter Forty-Two: The Great Sage Reverently Pays Homage to the Southern Sea, Guanyin Compassionately Binds Hong Hai**

The Sage said: *"Nature is the decree of Heaven.*
*Let its scope be as vast as Heaven’s, its duration as enduring as Heaven’s,*
*let it arise from me, not from Heaven—*
*yet it does not command one to indulge in fine food or sensual pleasures.*
*Thus, it is undivided Heavenly Principle, without vice.*

*When it manifests, it is also undivided Heavenly Principle, fully virtuous—*
*this is called *following Nature*.*

*If one follows Nature, it is *holding the Mean*, it is *True Suchness*,*
*it is *Inner Elixir*, Sagehood, Immortality, and Buddhahood.*

*But if there is even a hair’s breadth of partiality or perversity,*
*it is no longer undivided Heavenly Principle.*

*All partiality and perversity are evil, are demonic forces,*
*are the private desires of the human heart obscuring truth.*

*The undivided Heavenly Principle is nothing but *Ren*—*
*it is *compassionate virtue*."*

*To preserve the undivided Heavenly Principle, one must cultivate *qi*;
*to cultivate *qi*, one must still the heart;
*to still the heart, one must quiesce the mind;
*to quiesce the mind, one must gather righteousness;
*to gather righteousness, one must know speech;
*to know speech, one must remove obstructions;
*to remove obstructions, one must attain knowledge.*

*This is called *refinement*."*

*Within this chapter, the Pilgrim transforms into King Yumao,*
*turning the Dao into demonic forces—*
*this is not following Nature.*

*The father and son’s reverent meeting, courteous and proper,*
*is Nature, yet he acts within it.*

*The boy calls himself *“Ignorant Son,”*—*
*ignorance is obscuration, lacking clarity,*
*unable to attain knowledge—*
*this is Nature, yet truth cannot be seen through it.*

*Of all Heaven’s natures, none surpasses that of father and son.*
*The father deceives his son, mistaking a false son for the true one;*
*the son, in his ignorance, mistakes a false father for the true one.*

*The lesser demons all knelt and said:*
*“Great King, you cannot even recognize your own father!”*
*Words that lose the true for the false,*
*and obscure the Heaven-given nature of one’s birth.*

*To seek longevity while obscuring one’s Heavenly nature*
*is like asking a false father for one’s birth chart,*
*bothering Zhang Daoling to calculate the Five Stars of Ziwei*
*in hopes of matching Heaven’s immortal lifespan—*
*how could this succeed?*

*To defy Heaven’s decree and violate filial piety,*
*how is it different from striking one’s father and rebelling against one’s son?*
*When conscience awakens, how could one not blush with shame?*

*There are also those who falsely claim Daoist learning and misrecognize Heavenly nature,*
*just as the Pilgrim falsely impersonates the demon king,*
*pretending to hunt morality like a royal hunt.*

*“Sitting in the central seat of the south”—*
*occupying it without doubt.*

*What they calculate is the distant concern of securing one’s livelihood and old age;*
*what they boast of are their boundless transformations;*
*what they gather are the clever appearances of mimicking others;*
*what they uphold is the false austerity of thunder-fasts;*
*what they recognize are the celestial omens of the *Liuzhi* [六爻].*

This is a heartless, depraved act of evil, yet they know not they are devouring men, these demons of life’s corruption!
The Pilgrim’s transformation—from true to false, then back again—is but a display of his cunning, his laughter a mockery of the unknowing.

When he changes, let the unseeing open their blinded eyes;
when he laughs, let the ignorant shrink their probing heads—
for wisdom lies in exposing folly at its root,
not in clashing banners on the battlefield.
It is like the water-worker who strives against the current,
or the arsonist who seizes the wind.

*"No need to worry—I’ll fetch the Bodhisattva myself."*
*"Straight to the Southern Sea, to the cliffs of Lankā,*
*and prostrate myself in homage!"*

How clear the vision, how direct the path!

The Bodhisattva spoke in fury:
*"That wretch dares mimic my form!"*
With a sweep of his gem-studded alms-bowl,
he hurled it into the sea’s depths.

The Pilgrim scoffed:
*"This Bodhisattva’s fire has not yet cooled."*

Before he could finish, the waves churned—
a tortoise surfaced, bearing the bowl ashore,
and knelt in twenty-four obeisances.

*"Ah, the Keeper of the Bowl!"* said the Pilgrim.

The Bodhisattva commanded:
*"Pilgrim, take the bowl!"*
Not a drop could be moved.

*"You do not know,"* said the Bodhisattva,
*"that it was always empty—
but cast into the sea,
it now holds all its waters within.
What strength could you have to lift the ocean?
Thus, you cannot take it."*

Alas!

「Ah! How wondrous this is!

The commentator says: *"The tortoise bearing the bowl,*
*along with the later episodes of the lotus petals crossing the sea,*
*the Dragon Princess plucking hairs—*
*all these exchanges, leisurely unfolded,*
*seem unrelated to the main text,*
*merely serving as a foil to the Red Boy."*

*"Like the painter’s words:*
*'‘Fine grasses and fallen flowers make a brocade land,’*
*these fallen flowers are but embellishments*
*to adorn the fine grasses,*
*thus completing the brocade."*

*Yet this passage reveals the Immortal Master’s*
*application of profound truth,*
*crafting a marvelous form—*
*truly the core of the main text.*

*His imaginings and strokes*
*possess a divine, ghostly artistry,*
*beyond mortal reach.*
*Among a hundred chapters,*
*this stands as peerless masterwork!*

*Laozi teaches:*
*"Through kindness, one attains courage;
Through frugality, one attains breadth;
By not daring to lead the world,*
*one achieves enduring greatness."*

*In ancient times,*
*the Duke of Zhou and King Wu,*
*in their wrath, settled the land;*
*Confucius, in his wrath,*
*rectified the four cardinal directions—*
*great courage indeed.*

*Yet only through great kindness*
*could such great courage arise.*
*The demon’s guise as a false Bodhisattva,*
*deceptive yet plausible,*
*confuses truth with falsehood—*
*the foremost trick of evil spirits,*
*most destructive in its harm.*

*The Bodhisattva, in great kindness,*
*thus raged:*
*"That wretch dares mimic my form!"*
*"With a sweep of my gem-studded alms-bowl,*
*I cast it into the sea’s depths!"*
*Clear in vision, resolute in deed—*
*this is “Through kindness, one attains courage.”*

*The *Huainanzi* states:*
*"There is essence yet it is not used,*
*there is spirit yet it is not employed.*
*In harmony with the Great Primordial Purity,*
*one stands within the realm of utmost clarity."*
*This is the Way of frugality.*

*"‘Always an empty bowl,*
*cast into the sea,*
*now it holds all its waters within—*
*you cannot lift it.’"*
*The empty bowl is the epitome of frugality,*
*and only through such frugality*
*does one attain boundless breadth,*
*as in the saying:*
*"‘A sesame seed can contain Mount Sumeru,*
*a hair can swallow the great ocean.’"*
*This is “Through frugality, one attains breadth.”*

*The *Book of Documents* says:*
*"One must have capacity,*
*then virtue grows great;*
*one must endure,*
*then salvation is achieved."*
*This speaks of vast Qi/breath,*
*encompassing all with serene cultivation.*

*Among the myriad creatures,*
*the tortoise is the longest-lived,*
*taken as a symbol of guarding the female*
*and nurturing with wisdom.*
*The sage composed the *I Ching*’s *Yi Hexagram*,*
*its first line modeled on the tortoise,*
*to show how the virtuous one*
*cultivates themselves.*

*"‘Seeing the waves churn,*
*a tortoise emerges,*
*bearing the alms-bowl to the cliffs,’*
*it carries its burden with ease,*
*lifting what others cannot—*
*is this not*
*'By not daring to lead the world,*
*one achieves enduring greatness’?"*

*This contrasts sharply*
*with the Red Boy’s reckless triumph,*
*void of cultivation.*

*The Pilgrim bowed in reverence:*
*"This disciple does not know."*
*I too bowed in reverence:*
*"This disciple does not know."*
*Will those who read this book in ages to come,*
*and grasp my meaning,*
*also bow and say*
*"‘This disciple does not know’?"*

*"The Bodhisattva’s right hand lifts the bowl,*
*resting it on his left palm—*
*flowing effortlessly,*
*a display of mastery,*
*the third *Dhyāna* of perfect stillness."*

*Yet how does the water arise,*
*if the bowl holds the sea*
*and the tortoise dives beneath?*
*Unknown to the common eye,*
*the bowl’s contents are not mere water,*
*but the very Qi of the ocean—*
*formless, untouched by substance.*
*Thus the Bodhisattva declares:*
*"‘My bowl holds sweet dew,*
*not like the Dragon King’s spray,*
*which can extinguish that demon’s*
*threefold *Dhyāna* flame.’"*

*With the true water of *Dhyāna*,*
*he subdues the false fire of *Dhyāna*—*
*using spirit, not mere form,*
*exemplifying the art of perfect cultivation.*
*What need then for the mind’s wild flames?*

*When the mind is unrestrained,*
*it seeks dominance,*
*burning fiercely like wildfire;*
*when the mind is still and true,*
*it guards the female,*
*nurturing like sweet dew.*

*The wildfire*
*is the demon’s torment,*
*consuming the heart;*
*the sweet dew*
*is the elixir,*
*irrigating the soul.*
*The tortoise is indeed the Red Boy’s*
*tailored antidote.*

*As for the alms-bowl,*
*it cradles true Qi,*
*vast and tranquil,*
*not merely empty and detached—*
*this is the Dao of*
*"non-action yet transformation,*
*stillness yet creation."*

*Should one harbor*
*a hint of grasping or attachment,*
*they could never fathom its depths.*
*Thus the Bodhisattva again*
*illustrates the Dragon Princess’s*
*and the precious bowl’s reluctance to part,*
*showing that such treasures*
*are not easily obtained.*

*It is not the Bodhisattva who is hard to part from,*
*but the Pilgrim’s own*
*indulgence and stinginess*
*that make the Bodhisattva’s gifts difficult.*
*Hence, the tight-skin cauldron’s removal,*
*and the Bodhisattva’s words:*
*"‘You are at ease.’"*
*To let go is not to abandon,*
*but to transcend.*

*The Pilgrim plucking hairs,*
*fearing it might save his life,*
*the Bodhisattva says:*
*"‘Not a hair shall you pluck,*
*for even my treasure, Shàncái,*
*I cannot part with.’"*
*Stinginess thus makes parting hard.*

*Wealth and desire*
*are external temptations,*
*while Shàncái is the true nature’s*
*wondrous manifestation.*
*The Bodhisattva reveals:*
*Shàncái’s reluctance to part,*
*showing how one sees goodness*
*in wealth,*
*divines its use,*
*discerns the difficulty of letting go,*
*and awakens to the act of release itself.*

*This is where the Master*
*blends truth with metaphor,*
*logic with divine inspiration—*
*a realm akin to*
*"the Heavenly Maiden scattering flowers,"*
*not to be read lightly.*

*Emerging from filth yet pure,*
*the lotus stands alone,*
*thus its petals can serve as*
*the universal vessel of compassion,*
*blown by the breath of Dao,*
*dispelling all afflictions,*
*what fear of the boundless sea of suffering?*

*To even the emotions*
*and achieve harmony,*
*one must endure.*
*Thus the *Gāng* blade can form*
*the Bodhisattva’s seat of Dharma,*
*as he sits serene,*
*clouds gathering around,*
*unfazed by even the mightiest trials.*

*The Dragon Princess splits the lotus,*
*ascending to the other shore,*
*while Huì’àn leans on the cosmic *Gāng*’s power,*
*transforming into a lotus platform—*
*both reveal the clarity of true nature.*

*The Bodhisattva overturns the alms-bowl,*
*pours the water like thunder;*
*extends the willow branch,*
*turns the blade into a hook.*
*The reader may think:*
*"‘The water poured to quench the fire,*
*a preemptive strike;*
*the lotus seat to ensnare the blade,*
*a victory without battle—*
*the utmost of goodness.’"*

All have lost their subtlety.

They do not grasp
that overturning the alms-bowl like thunder’s roar
is itself *delusion*—
for it points to their delusion
and lets them awaken on their own.

To awaken with wisdom against delusion
only makes the deluded more so;
to delude with delusion
makes the deluded awaken themselves.
Thus the Dao of skillful guidance
is to let them awaken with goodness,
not to let them delude with goodness.

Sitting on the lotus platform to learn the Bodhisattva’s way,
that is awakening—
for they hear of the path to awakening
and know their own delusion.
To awaken the awakened,
yet the awakened seem deluded,
to delude the awakened
yet the awakened grow ever more awake.
Thus the law of skillful transformation
is to let them awaken fully,
not to let them delude fully.

The alms-bowl tilted writes the character *迷* (delusion),
*come, come, come*—
observe how distant the land is from the surging tides,
where does the little cart still gallop on its old tracks?

The blade’s tip becomes the platform of awakening,
*sit, sit, sit*—
who knows the glory of the hollow is but a trick of the edge?
How could one endure an empty blade swung to nothing?

The Wayfarer rages in anger,
the great compassion of skillful guidance;
the demon rages in anger,
the great awakening of being ensnared in delusion.

Wondrous indeed!
The Bodhisattva asks twice yet gives no answer,
quelling their reckless striving.

The demon strikes with one spear,
piercing the heart and exposing its core—
sitting there,
pointing to that very place—
how could it ever have been truly fixed?

One must know the mind of *non-abiding* (無住) and birth—
*strike, strike, go*—
only when the heart dies
is it truly born anew;
urgently seek to lay all down at once.

*"Three top supports"* (三个顶搭)
clearly mark the three stars of the mind,
supporting heaven and earth as the Three *Talents* (三才).
Do not thrust into the flames of fire.

*"Five binding straps"* (五个箍儿)
embody the five virtues within the body,
gathering the spirit and consolidating the *qi*,
restoring innate virtue—
rejoicing in the golden nest of ease.

*"Called the Child of Wealth"* (善财童子),
human nature is inherently good,
and all talents are good—
merely affirming their goodness.

This is the cultivation of the boundless *Hàorán* *qi* (浩然之氣),
revealing true nature and clarifying the mind,
the wondrous Dao of great compassion and great pity.

Its essence points to no other than *"rightness and stillness"* (正定),
hence the saying:
*"A single word can recognize the sands of the Ganges,*
*boundless and profound is the law’s power."*

**Forty-third Chapter**
*Black River Demon Captures the Monk*
*The Western Dragon Child Snatches the Turtle*
**Awakened One** says:
This passage follows the Black Boy’s ability to stabilize his true nature and perceive the great compassion—
when the true heart is clear, wild impulses dissolve.
The Black Turtle, unable to nurture its true nature, churns waves and follows currents—
when false desires stir, the true nature sways,
demonstrating the harm of letting nature be swayed by the heart’s movements.
The former preserves the heart,
this cultivates the nature.

The Bodhisattva takes away the sea’s waters,
the child returns to its right fruit,
the Wayfarer releases the Three Treasures and Eight Rules,
firmly vowing to journey west.
The fire-nature of self-arising is already subdued,
yet the water-nature of outward dispersion still lingers.
*"Suddenly hearing the sound of water"* stirs the heart again,
unable to keep the mind as still as water.

Thus the Wayfarer raises the *Heart Sutra* (多心經) again to clarify the Six *Thieves* (六贼).
Eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind—
the Six *Thieves* of Heaven;
color, sound, scent, taste, touch, and *dharma* (法)—
the Six *Thieves* of the World.
If the Six *Thieves* of Heaven are not understood,
the Six *Thieves* of the World will ride in separately;
if the Six *Thieves* of the World are not removed,
the Six *Thieves* of Heaven will steal together.
Mutually harming and robbing,
the vital *qi* is lost along with it—
all from failing to forget the artifices and kill the heart to invite this fate.
Hence the saying:
*"Summoning these six thieves in confusion,*
*how can one reach the Western Paradise to see the Buddha?"*

If one seeks success,
it must be through purifying the heart and nurturing the nature,
not letting the heart hold even a speck of love, desire, greed, anger, or delusion.

The harm of greed and delusion
is no greater than the Black Waters surging like tides,
the little turtle as a demonic force.
*"The Black Water River God’s domain in Hengyang Pass"* (衡阳峪黑水河神府)
refers to the Kidney Palace (肾宫),
where the true spirit resides.
The little turtle, relying on its strength,
seizes and plunders its domain—
that is the unruly *qi* of greed and delusion.
It calls itself *"the foolish nephew"* (愚甥),
clearly a confession of guilt.
The foolish one is he who confuses right and wrong—
compare it with the Black Boy’s *"foolish son"* (愚男),
both reveal their greedy ignorance,
not humility.

The turtle dwells in the Black Waters yet names itself *"pure"* (洁),
like a man harboring filthy thoughts yet unaware of his impurity.
The Dragon King tells the Great Sage:
*"This is my younger sister’s ninth son. Because his father-in-law delayed the rains,
he was sentenced by the Heavenly Tribunals to be beheaded by Wei Zheng,
leaving behind this nephew, who nurtures his nature and cultivates truth in the Black Water River,
unexpectantly committing such evil."*

The ninth son, the youngest son.
The turtle’s purity—its youngest son;
the turtle’s impurity—is it not the second son?
Seeing this, does my earlier note that the Old Dragon is Li Yuan hold true?

Its father was in the murky waters of Jingyang (泾阳),
and his rains came too late;
its son is also in the Black Waters of Hengyang (衡阳),
yet commits this evil.
Jing (泾) as Heng (衡),
perhaps the family custom.

It knows the Heavenly Tribunals sentenced Wei Zheng to behead its father,
yet does not know the Three Treasures journey west to retrieve scriptures,
to transcend and deliver its father;
nor does it know the Three Treasures retrieve scriptures
for whom’s sake—
with a muddled heart and perverse actions,
it even thinks of boiling the Tripitaka Master’s flesh for food,
a blazing lust of desire,
only caring to fulfill its cravings,
unknowing of its father’s nature,
unknowing of its own fate.

Alas!
Ignorance of nature and injury to filial duty—
what filth is worse than this?

「Its source already polluted, its current cannot but be unclean—
where then is purity to be found?

Within the chapter, the tale of the Heavenly Tribunals beheading the Black Waters Dragon is again raised,
to show that without cultivating the heart to nourish one’s nature,
one cannot serve the Heavenly Dao—
thus incurring the Heavenly Tribunals’ punishment.

Mao Kang gathered troops to avenge wrongs,
and in one battle, the dragon was captured—
the Tripitaka Master and Eight Rules were freed,
and the dragon was spared execution,
*"for the sake of my noble father’s face,"*
and sent westward.

Though the dragon’s accomplices were pardoned out of leniency,
this was truly inviting Heaven’s favor.

The heart governs the Six Desires,
and among them, the Black Waters Dragon’s desire is most difficult to restrain.

The immortal master composed another passage,
using veiled speech and allegory,
highlighting its core essence—
to awaken clarity of nature and purity of heart,
subtly contrasting with the Black Waters Dragon and its journey through the Underworld.
The passage merely points to its ambiguous heart,
and uses symbols to convey its meaning—
its intent is profound.

*"The River God summoned the art of obstructing the waters,
blocking the upper current.
Soon, the lower flow dried up,
and a great path opened."*

This is the method of uprooting and sealing the source,
forcing the waters against their nature
and preventing the lower flow—
truly the key to cultivating nature and attaining immortality.

The great path westward was revealed,
Red Boy was bound while the Black Crocodile returned,
and the Three Mysteries of pure cultivation were attained.

Yet why does the text say that whenever demons and monsters capture the Tripitaka Master,
they claim:
*"The Golden Cicada reincarnation,
a body of true yang refined over ten lifetimes—
if someone eats even a piece of his flesh,
it will extend their lifespan and grant eternal youth"*?

Because this text is written specifically for the Dao of Gold Elixir.
Those demons and monsters symbolize those who practice perverse, heretical methods,
hoping vainly for longevity—
they are likened to refining gold elixir into a tangible, substantial form,
hence the *"Golden Cicada reincarnation"*;
the *"true yang of the primordial body refined over ten lifetimes"*;
and the *"eating his flesh grants eternal youth"*.

They do not know that the Elixir of Rebirth is originally formless,
unlike the Tripitaka Master’s blood and flesh—
this is why they are considered heretical demons.

It boasts of its name, *"Mountain Until the Black River,"*
spanning tens of thousands of words,
a vast and profound discourse,
expounding the mysteries of the Dao,
all rooted in the benevolent cultivation of the heart
by Master Zhuang.

Some say this text belongs to the lineage of Zhong and Lü,
but they do not know it traces directly back to Mencius’ Dao.

The discerning may judge accordingly.

**Chapter Forty-Four: The Law Body and Primordial Fate Encounter the Ox-Cart’s Power**
**The Rectified Heart Overcomes the Heretical Demons at the Ridge Pass**

A scholar said: These three passages are specifically written to refute external Daoist sects.

External sects, like those seeking entry through side doors and alleys,
twisting and turning, devious and unorthodox,
are rarely able to attain true fruition—
why?

For those who advance at the proper time,
their foundation must align with the Heavenly Dao’s path.
External sects, however, are like galloping recklessly along walls and byways,
never finding their true path.

The multitude of heretical practices disrupts the scriptures,
their licentiousness only serves to destroy the body.

Within the chapter, the three Daoists—Peach Force, Deer Force, and Sheep Force—
embody the external sects in all their forms.

The external sects number three hundred and sixty,
but they are divided into three categories:
opening the Three Passes,
operating the Ox-Cart,
ascending the Ridge,
and the methods of mud pellets, chest supplementation, and returning essence—
all these are recorded in *The Yellow Court* and *The Spirit Pivot*,
along with the true scriptures of the immortals.
Later generations failed to receive the true transmission,
and passed on these methods in error—
they seem plausible but are fundamentally false,
the most likely to mislead and cause harm.

Guangchengzi said:
*"Cease your laborious efforts with the Ox-Cart and Elixir Furnace,
for the Blessed Embryo of the Crane and the Breath of the Tortoise
are naturally everlasting."*

Because the human body contains Heaven and Earth,
each inhalation and exhalation has its own roots and connections.
The Governing and Conception Vessels follow the movement of the qi,
forming the natural rotation of Heaven’s fate—
like the Ox-Cart.

Those who falsely practice opening the Three Passes,
turning the pulley,
and forcefully manipulate their essence,
disturbing their bones—
all these are unnatural,
contrary to Heaven and harmful to principle,
and sever the Great Dao.

They do not realize that the Ox-Cart is Heaven’s natural design,
its divine movement ceaseless—
once human interference begins,
it becomes choked and stagnant,
blood congeals and qi solidifies,
and strange poisons and chronic diseases arise—
this is truly the method of hastening death.

The border of Ox-Cart Country lies between the Black River and the Heaven-Piercing River,
embodying the meaning of the Ox-Cart’s stagnation.

The disciples heard the commotion
and assumed it was an earthquake, mountains collapsing,
thunderous claps of lightning,
and cries of people and neighing of horses—
all descriptions of unnatural, forced actions,
evoking dread and astonishment.

*"The Tripitaka Master saw many monks gathered in clusters,
pulling the cart with all their might,
and striking drums for power,"*
—this reveals their failure to harmonize the Five Phases,
to align with the natural unity of things,
and to follow the effortless Dao.

*"The cart was loaded with bricks, tiles, wood, and plants,"*
—this shows they were collecting dross, heavy and impure substances.

After recounting the high slopes, the narrow Ridge Pass, and the great pass,
*"How can the cart be pulled up such steep cliffs?"*
—all these directly point to their erroneous forcing of energy,
and their ignorance of the subtle marvels of the Ox-Cart’s natural rotation.

The Tripitaka Master transformed into the Cloud and Water Immortal,
and questioned the foreman Daoist about the reason—
then went straight to the riverbank,
passed the Twin Pass,
and descended the Ridge,
requiring no effort at all—
how effortlessly he moved with the circumstances!

The monks said:
*"He knows how to refine elixir and transmute mercury,
and turn stones into gold."*

If the external sects regard operating the Ox-Cart as internal alchemy,
and refining lead and mercury for consumption as external alchemy,
then this is their beginning and end—
leading the blind and believing in delusion,
like a madman or a wild horse,
and ultimately, never achieving success even unto old age.»

The lifespan may be slightly prolonged,
yet it is but a ghostly existence in a spectral abode.
Thus the venerable master said,
*"You cannot escape,"*
*"You cannot die."*
Neither death nor life—
not true longevity,
but merely prolonged suffering.

How could one attain the *arhat*’s journey to the Western Heaven for scriptures,
or the divine powers of the Heavenly Worthy of Equaling Heaven,
to redress this injustice among mortals?

The Tripitaka Master said:
*"Five hundred souls are kin to me."*
The Buddha spoke:
*"All sentient beings are my disciples."*
Originally boundless and impartial,
with neither inner nor outer distinctions—
yet now you cling so desperately—
what then is this vast compassion?

*"Unsheathing the Golden Hoop Staff,
a single strike to slay!"*
Just as Vajrapāṇi wields his demon-subduing scepter
to crush demons and deliver the monks.

The Tripitaka Master revealed his true form,
and the monks bowed in reverence,
begging him to subdue the demon and restore order.
*"Quickly drag the Ox-Cart past the Twin Pass,
through the Ridge,
lift it high and hurl it to shatter—
let the bricks, tiles, wood, and plants all tumble down the slope!"*

Truly excellent!
Truly excellent!

Restoring the original essence of the Law-body,
shattering the sluggishness of the demon’s strength,
upholding the loyal and virtuous single mind,
righting the crooked ridge of demonic deceit—
direct, swift, and resolute,
combining wisdom and courage.

Life and vitality—body, mind, essence, and breath—
everyone may preserve them whole.

Most wondrous is when the Great Sage plucks a hair,
each teaching twists it into the fingernail of the ring finger,
clenches it in a fist,
and calls—it answers instantly,
each summoning the Great Sage to appear and guard them,
so that no demonic intrusion may prevail.

The ring finger belongs to the heart,
speaking of how one’s thoughts may be as fine as hair—
firmly held in mind,
with every thought invoking the Sage,
how could there be any demonic obstruction?

Every person’s heart harbors Confucius,
every monk’s hand holds the Great Sage—
still and unmoving,
yet responsive when called—
the most profound and wondrous Dao.

The Master’s words are divine and wondrous;
readers must truly grasp their meaning.

This is the radiant wisdom,
like awakening from a dream—
when the old monk of Zhìyǔ Temple first saw the Tripitaka Master,
he bowed and called him "Grandfather"—
was it not Zhìbái Jinxīng saving human life in a dream?

The Three Monks secretly visited the Three Pure Ones’ Hall,
extinguishing the lamp’s light,
transforming into the Highest Venerable, Primordial Beginning, and Numinous Treasure,
demonstrating that Buddha is Taoist, Taoist is Buddha—
though teachings differ in schools,
their essence is one.

To neglect Zhìyǔ Temple
is to extinguish the Three Pure Ones’ Hall.

If both sides harbor deceit—
monks gluttonously stealing offerings,
Taoists hiding their ears and groping for the golden bell—
they invite the laughter of the discerning.

**Chapter Forty-Five: The Great Sage Leaves His Name at the Three Pure Ones’ Hall, the Monkey King Reveals His Law in the Country of Carrying the Chariot**

Wùyī Zǐ says:
This passage elucidates the elixir of the Saintly Water—
born of cultivation, not supplication;
true nature and emptiness are one,
relying entirely on divine efficacy,
not on sensory indulgence.

It shatters false paths,
pointing to ultimate truth.

Cool and detached in tone,
yet everywhere a warning.

The Three Daoists—Hǔlì, Lùlì, and Yánglì—
proclaimed themselves Great Immortals,
chanting sutras to avert calamities and seek longevity for the realm.
Yet ignorant of the Dao’s true essence,
how could they discern the Three Pure Ones’ authenticity?

They suspected the Celestial Vessel’s descent,
kneeling to beg for the Saintly Water elixir—
like common folk worshipping stars or invoking spirit-writing tablets,
praying for extended life.
Their delusion knows no bounds!

The Great Sage agreed to leave the elixir,
yet the "Three Immortals" carried it in a bucket,
a basin, or a bottle—
like mortals clinging to *Bāduànjǐn*, *Liùzìjué*, or *Shíliùzì hūxī*,
or refining autumn stone and red lead to swallow,
each sealing their own vessel—
far surpassing even the *Chénglù jīnjīng*,
yet still grasping at longevity and celestial favor.
How absurd!

The three monks each indulged in their own *niè*—
not jesting, but profound insight.
For swallowing saliva or inhaling qi
are both matters of *yin* substance;
autumn stone and red lead,
when refined, yield filth and impurities—
often stemming from *niè*.
Thus, the Sage spoke plainly:
*"You drink but the urine of your own niè!"*

Even the Three Teachings’ sages have referenced *niè* in speaking of the Dao:
The Buddhist scriptures say, *"The Dao lies in the dry excrement stake."*
The *Nánhuá* [Zhuangzi] declares, *"The Dao is in excrement and urine."*
The *Dàxué* [Great Learning] warns, *"Like hating foul odors."*
Yet even in the most putrid transformation lies divine marvel—
the receptive and pure restoring the original.
In the most turbid depths lies the purest essence.
*Niè* is not entirely unworthy of mention in the Dao—
yet how laughable that seekers of the Dao should fixate upon it!

Truly wise, the Great Sage said,
*"Just leave my name instead."*
For mortals, lost in wild speculation,
knowing not the Dao’s nature,
he must shout aloud:
**"Dao/Hao! Dao/Hao!**
**You fool, lost in such chaotic thought!"**

There are Three Pure Ones—
would they deign to descend to mortal form?
I shall reveal my true surname,
and make you understand.

The Wayfarer has no father or mother—
how then could he have a surname?
His surname was bestowed by the Ancestor of Bodhi,
the true transmission of life’s essence.

The surname is the very nature itself.
If you say, *"You take the Dao as your name,"*
do you truly know the Dao’s name?
Why such wild and groundless speculation?

Could the Three Pure Ones of highest sanctity
ever descend to this turbid world
and lightly cross over the common folk?
It is only because you do not know your true nature.

Now I shall reveal your true nature to you—
do you not know that all you consume
are but the urine of *niè*?
This is no forced interpretation—
observe *"Just leave my name instead"*—
why does it not leave a name,
but only speak of *"surname"*?
And why does it not leave a surname,
but only say *"true surname"*?

When you reach the closing line—*"fully realized in nature"*—
you will understand.

The Sage-Teachers used *"the Great Sage leaves a name"*
as a hook to draw attention,
to clarify the Dao’s true designation—
only the true nature itself.

In ancient times, the Divine Maiden conceived by Heaven’s grace,
and thus the character *"surname"* (姓) bears the radical *"woman"* (女).
For *"surname"* inherently contains the marvelous Dao
of nature’s generation and transformation.

Ah!
The surname is used to name,
the surname is used to represent nature,
the surname is used to name the Dao,
the surname is used to answer the call.

Spoken casually, yet each word is the Dao—
profound, unfathomable, divine!
Wondrous!

The Master and his disciples attended court, where the Old Daoist made a report, the Great Sage gave his account, and the Village Elder presented his petition—all recounting how the Carriage-Slow Kingdom sought rain through a contest of Buddhist and Daoist magical arts. The Sage-Teachers then explained the rain-invocation method to illustrate the vast difference between heterodox and orthodox Dao. It was not merely to showcase the Great Sage’s superior technique.

The Dao, fundamentally, is one nature permeating all things, revealing the true essence while harmonizing principle and practice.
